questions.text: A 45-year-old male is presented to the ED with severe tachycardia after a drug overdose. His family reports that he has been depressed. Past history of hypertension is present. Which one of the following drugs increases the heart rate in a dose-dependent manner?
questions.solution:
• Given clinical scenario is the overdose of a drug in a hypertensive patient which causes tachycardia, points towards class of anti-hypertensive which causes increases heart rate.
  • Direct vasodilators (Option D) regularly increase heart rate (by reflex tachycardia), and Minoxidil, a very efficacious vasodilator, causes severe tachycardia that must be controlled with β blockers.
  • Option A & C: Captopril (ACE inhibitors) and Losartan (ARB), do not significantly increase heart rate as they're predominantly acts by inhibiting RAAS. Compensatory responses to blood pressure lowering by these drugs are minimal.
  • Option B: Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretics, acts by Inhibition of Na+-Cl- co-transporters in the early distal tubule segment leads to diuresis. It lower blood pressure by reduction of blood volume. Compensatory responses to blood pressure lowering by diuretics are minimal.

questions.text: Parasympathetic nerve stimulation and a slow infusion of bethanechol will each
questions.solution:
While answering the question regarding action of parasympathetic (or sympathetic) drugs its best to rule out option Choice

(A) Ganglion cells and the end plate contain nicotinic receptors, which are not affected by bethanechol, a direct-acting muscarinic agonist.

(B) Parasympathetic nerve stimulation does not cause vasodilation (most vessels do not receive parasympathetic innervation Even though some muscarinic receptors might be present there.), so choice is incorrect.

(D) is not correct because the vagus slows the heart.

Efferent fibers in the vagus may cause bronchoconstriction. The answer is C

questions.text:
A year-old is brought to the ED having just ingested a large overdose of "X", is a weak acid with a pKa of 4.0. It is capable of entering most tissues. On physical examination, the heart rate is 130/min, blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 30/min. Which of the following statements about management in this case of "X" overdose is incorrect?
A. Absorption of the drug would be faster from the stomach than from the small-intestine.
B. More of the drug would be ionised at blood pH than at stomach pH.
C. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent.
D. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by giving NaHCO3, an alkalinising agent
E. Absorption of the drug would be slower from the stomach than from the small-intestine.
F. More of the drug would be unionised at blood pH than at stomach pH.
questions.solution:
Given scenario of overdose of drug "X", needs understanding of Henderson-Hasselbalch Relationship for the management. The Henderson-Hasselbalch relationship is clinically important when it is necessary to estimate or alter the partition of drugs between compartments of differing.

Here, drug "X", pKa = 4, weak acid will have drug absorption would be faster from the stomach (A is correct) because of More of the drug would be unionised at stomach pH. (B is correct) and Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NaHCO3, an alkalinising agent (D is correct ). Here in question, incorrect sentences are being asked thus, C, E and F are answer

choices.text: Decreased neuromuscular transmission and relaxation of skeletal muscle (during surgical anaesthesia)

questions.text: Actions and clinical uses of muscarinic cholinoceptor agonists include which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Muscarinic agonists cause accommodation and cyclospasm, the opposite of paralysis of accommodation (cycloplegia). Although not drugs of choice, in acute angle-closure glaucoma, this may result in a desirable increased outflow of the aqueous and a decrease in the intraocular pressure.

Muscarinic cholinoceptor agonists may cause bronchospasm, but have no effect on neuromuscular transmission.

They may cause diarrhea and must not be used in its treatment.

Succinylcholine blocks the action of acetyl-choline at the nicotinic receptor.

choices.text: Renin activity-Increased, AT-2 level-decreased, Aldosterone level-decreased, Urinary Sodium-decreased
Renin activity-Increased, AT-2 level-Increased, Aldosterone level-decreased, Urinary Sodium-Increased
Renin activity-Increased, AT-2 level-Increased, Aldosterone level-Increased, Urinary Sodium-Increased
Renin activity-decreased, AT-2 level-decreased, Aldosterone level-decreased, Urinary Sodium-Increased

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent headaches over the past 6 months. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Treatment with losartan is begun. Which of the following is the most likely effect of his new medication?
questions.solution:
• Losartan, ARBs(Angiotensin IIreceptor blockers), leads to increase in urinary sodium excretion, decreased vessel tone, lower levels of aldosterone. The combination of these lowers the blood pressure. Due to a loss of negative feedback regulation, treatment with ARBs typically leads to increased renin levels and increased renin activity, which in turn leads to increased levels of angiotensin II.
  • Option A: This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril),
    • It inhibits conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, resulting in low levels of angiotensin II. Angiotensin II mediates sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, vasoconstriction, and aldosterone release. Hence, decreased activation of angiotensin II receptors would lead to an increase in urinary sodium excretion, decreased vessel tone, and lower levels of aldosterone. The combination of these effects lowers blood pressure.
    • Due to a loss of negative feedback regulation, treatment with ACE inhibitors would typically lead to an increase in renin levels and renin activity.
  • Option C: This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with aldosterone receptor antagonists (e.g., spironolactone),
    • It competitively binds to aldosterone receptors in the late distal tubule and the collecting ducts, inhibiting the effects of aldosterone. Inhibition of aldosterone leads to decreased sodium reabsorption resulting in increased urinary sodium excretion.
    • Due to a loss of negative feedback regulation, treatment with aldosterone receptor antagonists leads to an increase in renin activity and downstream renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) components (i.e., angiotensin II) and aldosterone, causing an increase in vessel tone.
  • Option D: This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with direct renin inhibitors (e.g., aliskiren).
    • Direct inhibition of renin decreases renin activity, which leads to lower levels of angiotensin II (AT II) and aldosterone. Decreased levels of AT II and aldosterone result in decreased vessel tone and decreased sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, resulting in increased urinary sodium excretion.
  • The same combination of effects could also be explained by treatment with beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol). Beta-blockers inhibit the production and release of renin, which leads to suppression of the downstream renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) components (i.e., angiotensin II and aldosterone) and, subsequently, mildly decreased vessel tone and increased urinary sodium excretion.

questions.text: An investigational study, a newly synthesized drug is found to have antihypertensive effects. Increasing drug concentrations can cause increase in arteriolar radius and decrease beta cell insulin secretion. The mechanism of action of which of the following drugs most closely resembles the mechanism of action of the experimental drug?
questions.solution:
• The experimental agent is able to do both vasodilation and to decrease the release of insulin in response to glucose. The question is which known drug has similar effects. The answer is diazoxide, a K+ channel opener with hyperglycemic effects;
  • Diazoxide is a direct acting peripheral vasodilator that decreases both systolic and diastolic blood pressure. Specifically, diazoxide opens K channels on vascular smooth muscle, causing hyperpolarization and vasodilation, resulting in a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance. Opening K channels on pancreatic beta cells causes hyperpolarization and decreased calcium entry through voltage-gated calcium channels. As a result, diazoxide decreases insulin secretion in response to glucose.

choices.text: Procaine penicillin G intramuscularly as a single dose plus oral probenecid

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents with complaint of dysuria and urethral discharge. Gram stain of the urethral exudate shown below. Most appropriate treatment of in this patient is.
questions.solution:
• Given clinical scenario of urethral discharge along with Gram stain of the showing Gram-negative diplococci within PMNs suggest diagnosis of Gonorrhoea.
  • Treatments of choice for gonorrhoea include a single dose of ceftriaxone (IM). Because of the high incidence of beta-lactamase-producing gonococci, the use of penicillin G (Option C) or amoxicillin (Option B) is no longer appropriate for gonorrhoea. Similarly, many strains of gonococci are resistant to tetracyclines. Alternative drugs for gonorrhoea include cefixime or azithromycin.
  • Option D: Meropenem is used as Last-resort drugs (used only in life-threatening infections or after other antibiotics have failed) because of the significant adverse effects. Used in Intraabdominal infections, infections caused by Enterobacter spp. and ESBL-producing gram-negative bacilli.

questions.text: The dotted line represents an action potential following the infusion of the pharmacological agent into cardiomyocytes. The results shown in the graph are most likely caused by which of the following agents?
questions.solution:
The graph shows a ventricular action potential. The drug changes the duration of the rapid upstroke of the action potential (phase O) without significantly changing the overall duration of the action potential. It shows the effect of class IC antiarrhythmics. It acts by slow opening of voltage-gated sodium channels and decreases the slope of phase 0 while still maintaining the AP duration. Class IC antiarrhythmics also exhibit use dependence, further decreasing the slope as heart rate increases.

Although both class IA (Option D: Quinidine) and IB (Option B: Lidocaine) also exhibit slow opening of voltage-gated sodium channels and decrease the slope of phase 0, they prolong and shorten the AP duration, respectively.

Verapamil, a non-DHP CCB, class 4 drug, effective in arrhythmias must traverse calcium-dependent cardiac tissue such as the AV node. Here, the experiment is done on cardiac myocytes and AP shown is also of cardiac myocytes, not pacemaker. Thus, it cannot be the correct answer.

questions.text: A 11-year-old child is having learning difficulties at primary school. He has brief lapses of awareness with eyelid fluttering that occur every 10-20 min. Electroencephalogram (EEG) studies reveal brief 3-Hz spike and wave discharges appearing in all leads. Which drug would be not effective in this child?
questions.solution:
• Given clinical scenario of child with learning difficulties and brief lapses of awareness with eyelid fluttering suggestive of Absence Seizure which can be confirmed by EEG showing typical 3-Hz spike and wave
  • Option A & B: First line drug for the treatment is Ethosuximide > Valproate.
  • Option C: However, Clonazepam can be used but exerts troublesome CNS-depressant effects, and tolerance develops with chronic use.

FIRST LINE DRUG

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with epilepsy refractory to medical therapy is hospitalised for deep brain stimulation. This new modality uses a pacemaker-like device to stimulate which of the following structures?
questions.solution: • Deep brain stimulation (DBS) therapy uses a pacemaker-like device to deliver targeted electrical stimulation to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. The therapy is FDA-approved with conditions for adjunctive treatment for partial-onset seizures in adults with medically refractory epilepsy. DBS is also FDA-approved for treatment of advanced Parkinson disease and essential tremor.

questions.text:
Pharmacotherapy with carvedilol is initiated for patient with Idiopathic recurrent atrial fibrillation. Compared to treatment with propranolol, which of the following adverse effects is most likely?
1. Bradycardia
2. Hyperglycemia
3. Bronchospasm
4. Hypotension
questions.solution:
• Hypotension (low blood pressure) is a potential adverse effect associated with both carvedilol and propranolol due to their beta-blocking properties. While carvedilol's additional alpha-blocking activity can lead to more pronounced vasodilation, it's important to note that hypotension is a potential side effect of both drugs.
  • Bradycardia (slow heart rate) can occur with both carvedilol and propranolol, and it's not necessarily more likely with carvedilol.
  • Hyperglycemia (high blood sugar levels) is another potential adverse effect of both drugs. It is a shared risk and is not necessarily more likely with carvedilol.
  • However, the most likely additional adverse effect when using carvedilol compared to propranolol is not bronchospasm (Option 3). While bronchospasm can be a concern with certain medications, it is not typically associated with beta-blockers like carvedilol or propranolol.

So, the most accurate choice is:

D) 4 only

This option correctly identifies hypotension as a potential adverse effect shared by both drugs and highlights that the other mentioned adverse effects (bradycardia and hyperglycemia) are not necessarily more likely with carvedilol compared to propranolol.

questions.text: Which of the following/s is/are seronegative arthritis?
questions.solution: Seronegative arthritis refers to a group of four chronic diseases - ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis. All of them are negative for rheumatoid factor, they're all positive for hla-b27, and they typically all run in families.

choices.text: Continue current antibiotics and start griseofulvin
Continue current antibiotics and start amphotericin B
Stop current antibiotics and start itraconazole
Stop current antibiotics and start amphotericin B

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with leukemia was undergoing chemotherapy. During treatment, she developed a systemic infection. There was no erythema or edema at the catheter insertion site. Empiric antibiotic therapy was started with gentamicin, nafcillin, and ticarcillin intravenously. This regimen was maintained for 72 h, during which time the patient's condition did not improve significantly. Her throat was sore, shown below. On day 4, none of the cultures had shown any bacterial growth, but both the blood and urine cultures grew out Candida albicans. At this point, the best course of action is to
questions.solution:
• The antibiotic regimen should be stopped immediately, since the condition of the patient did not improve after 3 days of such treatment, the cultures were negative for bacteria, and the clinical picture suggested that the patient had a fungal infection.
  • This was subsequently confirmed by blood culture.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with depression is brought because of binging and purging for the past 6 months. Treatment with an antidepressant is begun and over the course of a few weeks of treatment, the dose is gradually increased. Two days after the most recent dosage increase, the patient develops seizures and is brought to the emergency department. Which of the following antidepressants is most likely responsible for the symptoms seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Bupropion (Wellbutrin) is a norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor antidepressant indicated for the treatment of major depressive disorder as well as smoking cessation.
  • Whereas antidepressants are widely used to treat eating disorders, bupropion is contraindicated in patients with a current or prior diagnosis of bulimia or anorexia nervosa because a higher incidence of seizures has been noted in these patients secondary to metabolic disturbances.
  • The risk of seizure is dose-related and is contraindicated for patients with seizure disorder and for those who are discontinuing from benzodiazepines or antiepileptic drugs.
  • It should be used with caution in patients with head injuries, taking medications that also lower the seizure threshold (e.g., antipsychotics, tricyclic antidepressants), metabolic disorders, or taking drugs with stimulant properties.
  • Bupropion also has stimulant-like effects (tachycardia, insomnia, weight loss). It differs from the SSRIs in that it is not generally associated with sexual side effects.

questions.text: Which of the following blood glucose readings is diagnostic of gestational diabetes according to IADPSG criteria?
questions.solution:
• The screening for Diabetes mellitus should be performed in women at the first prenatal visit
  • First trimester screening is performed for high risk women according to ADA while ACOG advocates universal screening for all women
  • The diagnosis of Gestational Diabetes mellitus is made if either one of the following is satisfied:
    • Fasting blood glucose > 92 mg/dl
    • 1 hr post OGTT > 180 mg/dl
    • 2 hr post OGTT > 153 mg/dl
  • If fasting blood glucose is more than 126 mg/dl or 2-hour post glucose load value is > 200 mg/dl, the diagnosis of overt diabetes mellitus is made

Reference: ADA Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes 2023

choices.text: Reduce her dose of BD mixed insulin by 50%
Reduce her dose of BD mixed insulin by 20%
Check a random cortisol to rule out Addison's disease
Change her to a basal bolus regime

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman came to the diabetes clinic with her two children. This is her third pregnancy and although not normally diabetic, she was diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus. Recent fasting plasma glucose levels have been in the range of 80-90 mg/dl and she is taking BD mixed insulins. Later that evening she collapses while shopping and is brought to the Emergency Department with blood glucose of 56 mg/dl. Which of the following represents the most appropriate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This lady's fasting plasma glucose levels are appropriate, but taking a BD mixed insulin regime is probably not appropriate to her lifestyle where her mealtimes and portion sizes may be slightly irregular given the fact that she has two other children to manage.
  • A basal bolus regime would give her more flexibility in varying insulin dose.
  • The coexistence of Addison's is unlikely and increasing the size of her meals would only promote more excess weight gain and worsening insulin resistance.

Reference: ADA Standards of Diabetes Care - 2023

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of headaches and sweating. Her mother had renal calculi and died of a tumour in her neck. On examination a nodule is felt in the patient's neck in the region of the thyroid gland. A surgeon advises complete thyroidectomy. What is the most important investigation the surgeon must undertake prior to surgery?
questions.solution:
• This patient probably has medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, which is usually associated with phaeochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism as part of the MEN-2A syndrome.
  • Here, the serum TSH level is unchanged, while a 24-h urine test for 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid is performed for the diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome.
  • Phaeochromocytoma must be excluded before surgery. If present, the effect of catecholamines must be blocked prior to surgery.
  • MEN-1 is associated with Pituitary adenoma, Parathyroid hyperplasia and Pancreatic tumours.
  • MEN-2A (multiple endocrine neoplasia) is associated with Parathyroid hyperplasia, Medullary carcinoma thyroid and Pheochromocytoma
  • MEN-2B is also associated with a marfanoid appearance, Mucosal neuromas whereas MEN-2a is not.

questions.text: In a hypothyroid patient becoming pregnant, dose of levothyroxine should be?
questions.solution:
• The dose of levothyroxine may need to be increased by 30-45% during pregnancy and returned to previous levels after delivery
  • Five factors alter thyroid function in pregnancy:
    1. The transient increase in hCG during the first trimester, which weakly stimulates the TSH-R;
    2. The estrogen-induced rise in TBG during the first trimester, which is sustained during pregnancy
    3. Alterations in the immune system, leading to the onset, exacerbation, or amelioration of an underlying autoimmune thyroid disease;
    4. Increased thyroid hormone metabolism by the placental type III deiodinase; and
    5. Increased urinary iodide excretion, which can cause impaired thyroid hormone production in areas of marginal iodine sufficiency.
  • The World Health Organization recommends a daily iodine intake of 250 μg during pregnancy and lactation, and prenatal vitamins should contain 150 μg per tablet.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation was prescribed medication to prevent stroke. She develops a lesion as shown in the photograph taken fourth and six days after the drug was begun respectively. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for the findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Warfarin, a coumarin anticoagulant, inhibits epoxide reductase, which blocks the ability to activate vitamin K.
  • This prevents the vitamin K-dependent gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors Il, VII, IX, and X, thus inhibiting their synthesis.
  • Warfarin similarly inhibits the vitamin-dependent synthesis of protein C and S, which have anticoagulant properties resulting from their inhibition of activated factors VIll and V.
  • Because warfarin acts by inhibiting the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent factors, the factors affected first will be those with the shortest half-lives, which are protein C and factor VIla.
  • Thus, warfarin has an initial paradoxical procoagulant effect because of a rapid reduction in protein C, while activity of most of the endogenous clotting factors (vitamin-dependent factors within the common and intrinsic coagulation pathways, I, IX, and X) persists.
  • This can lead to a state of hyper-coagulability and thrombosis. Warfarin may cause necrosis of the skin (typically on the breasts, buttocks, thighs, and abdomen) generally during the first several days of therapy.
  • The lesions are initially sharply demarcated, erythematous, and purpuric. They may resolve, or progress to large, irregular, hemorrhagic bullae that can eventually become necrotic.
  • Patients receiving a large loading dose of warfarin or who have an existing protein C deficiency are most susceptible. Warfarin should be discontinued immediately, and heparin, vitamin K, and protein C have been used in therapy. Despite treatment, approximately 50% of patients will require skin grafting.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions have a predisposition to right sided valvular pathologies?
questions.solution:
The conditions that can lead to predominant / exclusive right sided valvular pathologies include:

  • Carcinoid syndrome
  • Ebstein anomaly (Tricuspid regurgitation)
  • Arrhythmogenic RV cardiomyopathy (TR)
  • RVMI (TR due to papillary muscle dysfunction)
  • Infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers (TR)

questions.text: A 54-year-old female with type 2 diabetes is admitted with diarrhea and vomiting. She has noticed small amounts of blood in her stools. The vomiting had commenced one day after having a non-vegetarian diet. The patient's type 2 diabetes is treated with diet alone. Stool cultures taken by the GP reveal Campylobacter jejuni.Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Campylobacter is a leading cause of diarrhoeal illness, often caused by ingestion of undercooked meat harboring the pathogen.

It is also a major cause of traveller's diarrhea.

The use of antibiotic therapy for the management of Campylobacter infection in adults is controversial. Antibiotic of choice in this infection is erythromycin, though ciprofloxacin and tetracycline may also be appropriate.

However, appropriate fluid replacement and anti-emetics are initially indicated - most units advocate no antibiotic treatment.

Antibiotics are not recommended in patients with nontyphoid Salmonella, Campylobacter, STEC, Aeromonas, or Yersinia, except in severe disease, because they do not hasten recovery or reduce the period of fecal bacterial excretion

questions.text: A 23-year-old student presents for review. She is distressed by the fact that she is overweight and is embarrassed of excessive facial hair. She also notices that she appears to have more generalized body hair than other women. On further history, she can sometimes miss a couple of menses, but pregnancy testing is consistently negative. Her mother apparently had similar problems in her youth, took a while to conceive and now has type-2 diabetes. Testosterone is just above the upper limit of normal range, her LH:FSH ratio is increased and prolactin is normal. Which diagnosis fits best with this woman's clinical picture?
questions.solution:
• PCOS is said to occur in 3% of adult women.
  • Symptoms usually begin around the time of menarche and the diagnosis is often made in adolescence. Obesity is present in around 40% of sufferers and there is an increased association with type-2 diabetes due to insulin resistance.
  • Biochemical abnormalities characteristically include a mildly raised testosterone level and an increased LH: FSH ratio.
  • The cornerstone of management is life style modifications to achieve weigh reduction.
  • The use of OCPs can reduce the androgen levels and help achieve regular menstrual cycles.
  • The anovulation associated with PCOS is treated with ovulation induction agents like Clomiphene citrate and Letrozole
  • Hyperprolactinemia is unlikely as her prolactin is normal.

questions.text: A 40 year old man has a 2 year history of increasing shortness of breath. This is worse with exertion e.g. climbing the stairs at home and is even slightly so at rest. He is a non-smoker. On examination, his pulse is 95 beats/min and his blood pressure is 140/95 mmHg. He has finger clubbing and a crackling noise at the end of inspiration over the bases of the lungs. There was no ankle oedema Lung function tests show :FVC 2.5 L (predicted 3.2 )FEV1 2.1 L (predicted 2.4)FEV1 % 76% (predicted 75%)Diffusing Capacity: Gas Transfer Factor for carbon monoxide: DLCO 17 ml/min/mmHg (predicted:25 ml/min/mm Hg)Which one of the following diagnoses is likely?
questions.solution:
• A reduced FVC, with normal FEV1, FEV1% and PEF usually indicates restriction of lung volume. KCO (transfer factor) is also reduced in fibrotic lung disease, as in this case.
  • The additional findings of inspirational crackles and clubbing suggests the diagnosis of cryptogenic fibrosing alveolitis.

questions.text: Most common organism causing overwhelming infection in post-splenectomy patients is:
questions.solution:
Splenic individuals are at increased risk of overwhelming post-splenectomy infections (OPSI).

Patients without spleen are 58 times more likely to succumb to sepsis than the general population.

Most OPSIs occur within 2 years of splenectomy. Most OPSIs are caused by encapsulated organisms such as S. pneumonia, H. influenzae & N. meningitidis. Streptococcus pneumoniae accounts for up to 40-70% of cases of OPSI.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents with difficulty speaking. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He is currently on aspirin, simvastatin, amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide. On examination the patient is awake, his blood pressure is 150/70 mmHg. His pulse is irregularly irregular. He has 4/5 strength in the right arm and leg and 5/5 strength on the left. When asked to point to the window he does this correctly. When told to raise his arms and place his hands out he is seen to have a pronator drift on the right. He is shown a pen and asked what it is. He responds fluently but makes some paraphasic errors. He is asked to use it appropriately and begins to write on a piece of paper. When asked to repeat 'Today is a sunny day', he is unable to do so.Which of the following terms best describes these signs?
questions.solution:
• In Broca's or nonfluent or expressive aphasia the patient is unable to name objects with poor comprehension and repetition. It localises to the Broca's area in the left posterior inferior frontal gyrus.
  • In transcortical motor aphasia, which localises to the anterior superior frontal lobe, the patient is has good comprehension and repetition but has halting, effortful speech. Patients also have impaired writing skills.
  • Transcortical sensory aphasia is characterised by impaired auditory comprehension with intact repetition and fluent speech, and is caused by damage to the temporal lobes. It differs from Wernicke's aphasia in that patients still have intact repetition, and exhibit echolalia (the compulsive repetition of words). Improvement may be seen with speech therapy.

  • Anomic aphasia (also known as nominal aphasia) results in word finding difficulties. On closer examination there may also be repetition problems and comprehension problems but these are typically mild compared to other aphasia syndromes.
  • This scenario describes conduction aphasia. It is characterised by frequent speech errors, impaired repetition, reduced phonological short-term memory and naming difficulties.
  • In contrast to other forms of dysphasia, speech output is otherwise fluent and grammatically correct. Comprehension is intact. It is thought to be caused by left temporo-parietal region damage.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is referred with abnormal liver function and undergoes a liver biopsy. Which of the following count against hepatic cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
Granuloma formation is not classically seen in cirrhosis, which can be micro-or macronodular in type.

In the micronodular form, the nodules are less than 3 mm across with uniform liver involvement-seen in alcohol or biliary disease.

In the macronodular form, there are larger nodules, classically seen in chronic viral hepatitis.

questions.text: A 54 year old man has left sided hearing loss and vertigo. On examination, he has an absent corneal reflex on the left. There is also mild left sided facial weakness. Which one of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Cerebellopontine angle (CPA) tumours can cause vertigo, unilateral hearing loss. Large tumours may cause subtle facial weakness, decreased corneal reflex, and facial dysesthesia. If there was ophthalmoplegia or chemosis, then a cavernous sinus thrombosis would be more likely (it can also cause absent corneal reflexes).
  • Option A: Frontal lobe tumour would present with prominent behavioural and personality changes, apraxia and headache.
  • Option B: The clinical presentation of CVT is highly variable. The onset can be acute, subacute, or chronic. Headache (of gradual, acute, or thunderclap onset) is the most frequent symptom, occurring in almost 90 percent of patients, and may occur as part of an isolated intracranial hypertension syndrome, with or without vomiting, papilledema, and visual problems.
  • Option C: The major otologic complication of VZV reactivation is the Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which typically includes the triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles in the auditory canal or on the auricle

questions.text: A 38 year old athlete has pain on abduction of her arm, particularly when resisted.Which tendon pathology is affected?
questions.solution: Pain in abduction between 60- 120 degrees is due to Rotator cuff tendinitis. Of the rotator cuff the most commonly involved is the Supraspinatus tendon. Infraspinatus and Teres Minor are rarely invoved. Biciptial tendinitis is rare when compared to rotator cuff tendinitis.

questions.text: A 65 year old lady had a fall and fractured femur. A DEXA scan shows reduced bone mineral density consistent with osteoporosis.What treatment should be given to reduce the likelihood of future fractures?
questions.solution:
Management of osteoporotic fractures are treatment of the fractures along with management of osteoporosis.

The management of osteoporosis involves:

  1. Reduction of risk factors: smoking cessation, weight reduction etc
  2. Nutritional: Calcium and Vitamin D supplements, Proteins adequately
  3. Pharmacological measures: Bisphosphonates are the mainstay.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with a two-month history of progressive painless weakness affecting the proximal arms and legs. He has noticed difficulty getting out of a low chair and some difficulty swallowing but denies any rashes or visual symptoms. Investigations shows a CK of 5000 IU/l.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Proximal muscle weakness with high CPK suggests an inflammatory myopathy. Among the options Polymyositis is an Inflammatory myopathy. GBS does not cause elevated CPK. Hypothyroidism may cause weakness but here there are no clues to suggest a hypothyroidism. PMR causes girdle pain. Weakness is rare.

  • Polymyositis classically presents with relatively painless progressive proximal muscle weakness. Dysphagia is common but the ocular muscles are very rarely involved unlike myasthenia gravis where this is a predominant feature.
  • Diagnosis of polymyositis confirmed by elevated muscle enzymes (creatine kinase) and typical EMG and muscle biopsy findings.

questions.text: Is L-Asparaginase useful for the treatment of?
questions.solution: Induction regimens are centered around vincristine, glucocorticoids, and anthracyclines with or without cyclophosphamide or cytarabine. L-Asparaginase is the only ALL-specific drug and is now more intensively used in adults. Pegylated asparaginase has the advantage of a significantly longer period of asparagine depletion. Dexamethasone is often preferred to prednisone because it penetrates the blood-brain barrier and also acts on resting leukemic blast cells

questions.text: Slow Conduction velocity is seen with which of the following nerve fibres?
questions.solution: C type of fibres are the slowest conducting fibres which are Postganglionic Sympathetic nerve fibres.

questions.text: Lesion in which lobe will lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination?
questions.solution:
Lesion in the parietal lobe will lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination.

Parietal lobe:

Area 3, 1 and 2 are meant for perception of sensations, especially the cortical sensations (stereognosis, tactile localization and two-point discrimination), fine touch, proprioception and vibration.

Area 5 is more involved in processing of somatosensory information to produce movement.

Area 7 primarily processes visual information in order to produce not only movement, but also arousal, attention and emotion.

In Bilateral parietal lesion, there is inability to copy an object or even a simple design which is called constructional apraxia. Apraxia means inability to perform organized movements in the absence of paralysis.

Other options:

Option A: Temporal lobe is divided into three regions: Superior temporal gyrus, inferior temporal gyrus and mediobasal portion of temporal lobe. Superior Temporal Gyrus consists of Brodmann's area 22, 41, and 42 which is primarily concerned with audition. Inferior Temporal Gyrus consists of Brodmann's area 20, 21, and 37 which is primarily concerned with vision. Mediobasal Portion of Temporal Lobe concerned with limbic functions and olfaction.

Option C: Occipital lobe is the area of the brain posterior to the parieto-occipital sulcus. It is mainly concerned with vision. It consists of areas 17, 18 and 19.

Option D: Frontal lobe is responsible for social behaviour, emotional response and personality. Lesions in it lead to anaemia, incontinence, impaired memory and antisocial behaviour.

choices.text: Birbeck granules is seen on histopathological examination
Clonal neoplasm of myeloid dendritic cells

questions.text: A patient with lytic lesions on the skull is suspected of a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Which of the following findings is not true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
LCH is clonal neoplasm of myeloid dendritic cells which characteroistically has BRAF p.V600E mutation. Birbeck granules are seen on electron microscopy, not on histopathology.

The term histiocytosis is used for a group of proliferations of dendritic cells, Langerhans cells or macrophages and includes both benign and malignant examples. While histiocytic sarcoma, Langerhans cell sarcoma and dendritic cell sarcoma are clearly malignant lymphomas and are uncommon, monoclonal proliferation of Langerhans cells are grouped under Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) and are somewhat more common. LCH includes three clinicopathological related conditions occurring in children: eosinophilic granuloma, Hand-Schuller-Christian disease and Letterer-Siwe syndrome. As a group, all the three conditions are associated with proliferation of 3 types of cells: histiocytes, lymphocytes and eosinophils. Earlier, this group was referred to as histiocytosis-X but now following facts about this group are known:

Firstly, histiocytosis-X are not proliferations of unknown origin (X-for unknown) but proliferating cells are actually Langerhans' cells of marrow origin. Langerhans' cells are normally present mainly in the epidermis of the skin but also in some other organs.

Secondly, the three conditions included under histiocytosis-X are actually different expressions of the same basic disorder. This concept has emerged from 2 features:

  • Demonstration of common antigens on these cells by immunohistochemical stains for S-100 protein, CD1a and HLA-DR.
  • Electron microscopic demonstration of histiocytosis-X bodies or Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm. These are rod shaped structures having dilated tennis-racket-like terminal ends. Their function is not known but they arise from receptor mediated endocytosis of langerin found in human epidermal cells, a protein involved in Birbeck granule biosynthesis.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis-eosinophilic granuloma. Bone biopsy shows presence of infiltrate by collections of histiocytes having vesicular nuclei mixed with eosinophils. B, Immunohistochemical stain with S-100 shows cytoplasmic and nuclear positivity.

questions.text: Patient with mediastinal mass was diagnosed with red cell aplasia. What is the most probable cause of aplasia?
questions.solution:
Most common primary tumour present in the anterior superior mediastinum is thymoma. Although thymus is a lymphoepithelial organ, the term thymoma is used for the tumour of epithelial origin. Most of the patients are adults. In about half the cases, thymoma remains asymptomatic and is accidentally discovered in X-rays. Other patients have associated conditions like myasthenia gravis or local symptoms such as cough, dyspnoea and chest pain.

MORPHOLOGIC FEATURES

Grossly, the tumour is spherical, measuring 5-10 cm in diameter with an average weight of 150 gm. Sectioned surface is soft, yellowish, lobulated and may be either homogeneous or contain cysts due to the presence of haemorrhage and necrosis.

Microscopically, the tumour has a thick fibrous capsule from which extends collagenous septa into the tumour dividing it into lobules. The histology of lobule shows various patterns. The tumour consists of neoplastic epithelial cells and a variable number of non-neoplastic lymphocytes.

Thymoma may be of following types:

Benign thymoma is more common. It consists of epithelial cells which are similar to the epithelial cells in the medulla of thymus and hence also called medullary thymoma.

Malignant thymoma is less common and is further of 2 types:

Type 1 is cytologically benign looking but aggressive and invades the mediastinal structures locally.

Type 2 is also called thymic carcinoma and has cytologic features of cancer. Further subtypes of epithelial malignancy may be squamous cell type (most common) and lymphoepithelial type. T

Thymomas are known for their association with paraneoplastic syndrome. These include: myasthenia gravis (most common), hypogammaglobulinemia, erythroid hypoplasia (pure red cell aplasia), peripheral T cell leukaemia/lymphoma, multiple myeloma, other autoimmune disease associations and other systemic malignancies.

questions.text: 20 year old female presents with blisters over skin and in oral cavity .Her skin biopsy shows a special pattern on immunofluorescence .What is incorrect regarding this disorder?
questions.solution:
• Pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus are autoimmune diseases caused by antibody-mediated (type II) hypersensitivity reactions.
  • The pathogenic antibodies are IgG autoantibodies that bind to inter cellular desmosomal proteins (desmoglein types 1 and 3) found in the skin and mucous membranes. The antibodies disrupt the intercellular adhesive function of desmosomes and may activate inter cellular proteases as well. The distribution of desmoglein proteins within the epidermis determines the location of the lesions.
  • By direct immunofluorescence study, lesional sites show a characteristic fishnet-like pattern of intercellular IgG deposits.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris involves both mucosa and skin, especially on the scalp, face, axillae, groin, trunk, and points of pressure. The lesions are superficial flaccid vesicles and bullae that rupture easily, leaving deep and often extensive erosions covered with a serum crust.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is a rare disorder that occurs most commonly in older adults and more often in women than in men. Lesions are painful, particularly when ruptured, and frequently develop secondary infections. Most affected patients have oropharyngeal involvement at some point in their course.
  • Antibodies against hemidesmosomes are seen in bullous pemphigoid

questions.text: What is present in the center of target cells:
Golf ball inclusions are seen on _____stain and are associated with deletion of ____ alpha genes?
questions.solution:
Patients with alpha (α)-thalassemia present with a variable clinical phenotype depending on the number of α-gene deletions or mutations present. Person with one or two α-gene deletions is clinically asymptomatic while deletion of three α-genes leads to hemoglobin H (HbH) disease with marked reduction in α-globin chains. The excess β-globin chains form aggregates as unstable HbH (β4-tetramers) which are toxic and leads to hemolysis.Supravital stains such as brilliant cresyl blue (BCB), gentian violet, and new methylene blue upon prolonged incubation stain these precipitated globin chains. They appear as numerous dot size inclusions inside the red cells and are known as "golf ball inclusions.The majority of patients with HbH disease have compensated hemolytic anemia with an average Hb level of more than 9 g/dL.Patients with HbH disease may require infrequent blood transfusion, splenectomy, or chelation therapy.


(a) Peripheral smear showing microcytic hypochromic red cells with mild anisocytosis and target cells, (b) 1% brilliant cresyl blue preparation showing golf ball inclusions in red cells at 40 minutes of incubation.

questions.text: Type of stimulatory G protein involved in PIP2-Phospholipase activation pathway is-
questions.solution:
A number of G proteins distinguished by their α subunits have been described. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

Gs: Adenylyl cyclase activation, Ca2+ channel opening.

Gi: Adenylyl cyclase inhibition, K+ channel opening.

Go: Ca2+ channel inhibition.

Gq: Phospholipase C activation.

questions.text: A 42 yr old man came with AST 180, ALT-150 showing altered sensorium. Which of the following drugs would have been used to stabilize the patient?
questions.solution:
Lorazepam

Has slow oral absorption. Being less lipid-soluble than diazepam, its rate of entry in the brain is slower. The plasma t½ is shorter (10-20 hours); no active metabolite is produced, since it is directly conjugated with glucuronic acid, and is suitable for older patients.

However, it is quite sedative and capable of producing marked amnesia when injected i.v. Injection site complications are minor. Therefore, it is the only BZD recommended for i.m. use.

Lorazepam has been preferred for short lasting anxiety states, panic, OCD and tension syndromes, as well as for psychosomatic diseases and for i.v. use in status epilepticus.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent nephrectomy. Which of the following can be used for post-operative pain for this patient?
questions.solution:
Paracetamol (acetaminophen)

Actions The central analgesic action of paracetamol is like aspirin, i.e. it raises pain threshold, but has weak peripheral anti-inflammatory components.

Analgesic action of aspirin and paracetamol is additive. Paracetamol is a good and promptly acting antipyretic. Paracetamol has negligible anti-inflammatory action.

In contrast to aspirin and other NSAIDs, paracetamol does not stimulate respiration or affect acid-base balance; it does not increase cellular metabolism. It has no effect on CVS. Gastric irritation is insignificant-mucosal erosion and bleedingoccur rarely only in overdose. It does not affect platelet function or clotting factors and is not uricosuric.

questions.text: Following traumatic inoculation, a man presents with the following lesion due to lymphatic spread. Which organism is likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis, also known as "Rose Gardener's Disease," is a subacute or chronic infection caused by the saprophytic dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

The characteristic infection involves suppurating subcutaneous nodules that progress proximally along lymphatic channels (lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis).

It is dimorphic fungus

There are 3 types:

Histopathology shows 'Asteroid bodies'

questions.text: Which of the following is not bacteriostatic:
questions.solution:
Vancomycin

It is a glycopeptide antibiotic discovered in 1956 as a penicillin substitute which assumed special significance due to efficacy against MRSA, Strep. viridans, Enterococcus and Cl. difficile. Bactericidal action is exerted only on gram-positive cocci, Neisseria, Clostridia and diphtheroids.

questions.text: A patient of neurocysticercosis is on antiepileptic. The next step is:
questions.solution:
Neurocysticercosis:

When albendazole/praziquantel is used to kill cysticerci lodged in the brain, prednisolone 40 mg/day or equivalent is given for 2-4 weeks to suppress the reaction to the dying larvae.

questions.text: A diabetic female patient admitted with persistent vomiting with a history of consuming food from outside. BP-90/60mmHg; pH 7.52; HCo3- 26; Paco2 20+. Electrolytes Na- 123, K+- 3.2, Cl- 67meq/l. What is the cause of her ABG findings?
questions.solution: The pH is 7.52 which is alkalotic, the HCO3 is 26, which is high or at the upper limit of normal, so the acid base abnormality is metabolic alkalosis. Among the given options only persistent vomiting will cause metabolic alkalosis.

choices.text: Stabilise, NS 10 ml/kg followed by Insulin 0.1 U/kg/hr
Stabilise, NS 10 ml/kg followed by Insulin 0.2 U/kg/hr
Stabilise, NS 20 ml/kg followed by Insulin 0.1 U/kg/hr
Stabilise, NS 20 ml/kg followed by Insulin 0.2 U/kg/hr

questions.text: A 10-year child presented with tachypnoea and severe dehydration. He had a random blood glucose of 550 mg/dl, urine glucose 3+. The blood gas showed pH 7.1, bicarb of 7 mmol/L. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The child in the question has metabolic acidosis with hyperglycemia. It correlates with Diabetic Ketoacidosis.

  • According to ISPAD guidelines, depending on the amount of dehydration, the initial fluid bolus must be given over 1 hour. After 1 hour of bolus, Insulin drip is to be started.
  • The child in the question has severe dehydration, hence, he must be given bolus of 20ml/kg/hr of NS.

questions.text: Which of the following test would be done to confirm a case of angioedema?
questions.solution:
• Defects in complement regulatory proteins result in excessive inflammation or cell injury.
  • A deficiency of C1 inhibitor(C1 INH) gives rise to an autosomal dominant disorder called hereditary angioedema, C1 INH is an inhibitor of many proteases, including kallikrein and coagulation factor XII, both of which are involved in the production of vasoactive peptides such as bradykinin.
  • Therefore, defective C1 INH activity leads to over-production of bradykinin, which is a potent vasodilator.
  • Affected patients have episodes of edema affecting skin and mucosal surfaces such as the larynx and the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: HIV mainly infects cells bearing the which cell surface antigen.
questions.solution:
• HIV infects cells by using the CD4 molecule as a receptor and various chemokine receptors as coreceptors.
  • Binding of HIV gp120 to CD4 is essential for infection and accounts for the tropism of the virus for CD4+T cells and for CD4+monocytes/macrophages and DCs.
  • In molecular biology, CD4 is a glycoprotein that serves as a co-receptor for the T-cell receptor. CD4 is found on the surface of immune cells such as T helper cells, monocytes, macrophages and dendritic cells.

questions.text: On asking the name of the city that he lives in, an elderly patient having right hemispheric stroke replied, 'Jodhpur'. Next, on asking him the current year, he replied the same answer 'Jodhpur'. In fact, on asking any further question, he kept on giving the same reply. Such a formal thought disorder is known as ___________.
questions.solution:
• Perseveration is a formal thought disorder in which there is repetition of a particular response, such as a word, phrase, or gesture, despite the absence or cessation of a stimulus, usually caused by brain injury or other organic disorder rather than a psychopathology
  • It is clear that this is not a problem of volition, which helps differentiate it from verbal stereotypy, which is a frequent spontaneous repetition of a word or phrase that is not in any way related to the current situation
  • In verbal stereotypy, the same word or phrase is used regardless of the situation, whereas in perseveration a word, phrase or idea persists beyond the point at which it is relevant
  • Echolalia refers to meaningless repetition of another person's spoken words

questions.text: Match the following to their respective category of thought disorders:
questions.solution:
• Disorders of stream of thought: Flight of ideas, Prolixity, Circumstantiality
  • Disorders of possession of thought: Obsessions and Compulsions, Thought alienation
  • Disorders of content of thought: Delusions
  • Thought alienation: Thought broadcasting, Thought withdrawal, Thought insertion
  • Other formal thought disorders: Derailment, Loosening of Association

questions.text: The images below show a type of illusion in which there is a tendency for perception to impose a meaningful interpretation to a nebulous visual stimulus. Such a type of illusion is known as __________.
questions.solution:
• Pareidolia:
    • This is an interesting type of illusion, in which vivid illusions occur without the patient making any effort
    • These illusions are the result of excessive fantasy thinking and a vivid visual imagery
    • They cannot therefore be explained as the result of affect or mind-set, and so they differ from the ordinary illusion
    • Pareidolias occur when the subject sees vivid pictures in fire or in clouds, without any conscious effort on his part and sometimes even against his will

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl, diagnosed recently with depression and borderline personality traits, started visiting a male psychologist for psychotherapy sessions. After a few sessions, the psychologist observed that the patient started exhibiting clinging behavior towards him in form of frequently texting him about non-therapy related issues, requesting for more sessions, and often getting angry if the sessions got cancelled. Often, in the sessions, she would describe that he was a fatherly figure for her, having a strong resemblance to him in external appearance as well as the manner of talking. Such behavior of the patient towards the therapist is termed as ____________.
questions.solution:
• Transference is the process of the patient unconsciously and inappropriately displacing onto individual his or her current lifethose patterns of behavior and emotional reactions that originated with significant figures from earlier in life, often childhood
  • In the clinical situation the displacement is onto the psychiatrist, who is often an authority figure or a parent surrogate
  • It is important that the psychiatrist recognizes that the transference may be driving the behaviors of the patient, and the interactions with the psychiatrist may be based on distortions that have their origins much earlier in life
  • The patient may be angry, hostile, demanding, or obsequious not because of the reality of the relationship with the psychiatrist but because of former relationships and patterns of behaviors
  • Failure to recognize this process can lead to the psychiatrist inappropriately reacting to the patient's behavior as if it were a personal attack on the psychiatrist

questions.text: A 24-year-old man smelt burning rubber when he saw red signal at traffic lights and was convinced of the link between them. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
• This is a morbid form of synaesthesia, where a stimulus in one sensory field produces a hallucination in another.
  • In functional hallucination, the stimulus is also experienced along with the hallucination, and the hallucination requires the presence of another real sensation.
    • For example: 'I only hear the voices when water pipes are noisy.' (Option B)
  • Extracampine hallucinations are outside the limits of the sensory field. (Option A)
  • Primary delusions are false fixed beliefs even with contrary evidence (Option C)

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidaemia is admitted to the medicine unit for intravenous antibiotics for treatment of pneumonia. After 2 days he becomes increasingly anxious, with complaints of 'shaking' and sweating. His vitals demonstrate a temperature of 100.4 F, blood pressure of 170/97 mm Hg, pulse of 110 beats per min and respirations of 16 breaths/min. On examination he appears diaphoretic and flushed, with a coarse tremor of his upper extremities bilaterally. Laboratory test results are significant for slightly elevated AST, ALT and GGT. Review of his chart reveals a long history of daily, heavy alcohol use. When confronted with this information, the patient reluctantly admits to drinking 'one fifth' of vodka plus several beers daily, with little sobriety. His last drink was the day prior to admission. Administration of which of the following medications would be the most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient is most likely experiencing acute alcohol withdrawal which is characterized by signs of sympathetic nervous system stimulation such as:
    • Elevated vital signs
    • Diaphoresis
    • Flushing
    • Tremor
    • Insomnia and anxiety
  • It can occur anywhere between 1 and 4 days after cessation or significant reduction in alcohol intake
  • This patient's history, clinical presentation and laboratory results are consistent with a history of regular, heavy alcohol use.
  • Other complications of alcohol withdrawal include:
    • Withdrawal seizures(12-48 hours after the last drink)
    • Delirium tremens(24-96 hours after the last drink)
  • The mainstay of treatment for alcohol withdrawal is with:
    • Benzodiazepines - Lorazepam, Oxazepam
    • Either tapering the dose over several days or (in mild-to-moderate withdrawal), with a symptom-triggered approach, utilizing the Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment(CIWA) scale.
  • Acamprosate and Naltrexone are not appropriate for treating alcohol withdrawal, rather they are used in some cases to reduce craving and promote abstinence.(OPTION D)
  • Disulfiram is also not used to manage alcohol withdrawal, instead it is used as a deterrent to prevent a patient from consuming alcohol.(OPTION B)
  • Thiamine, while often depleted in alcoholics and necessary in the treatment of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, also does not address the pathophysiology of alcohol withdrawal.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man arrives at the emergency room with symptoms of gastrointestinal distress, muscle aches, rhinorrhoea, lacrimation and an anxious mood. He states that 'he wants to kick this thing once and for all'. Which of the following medications would be most helpful in ameliorating his symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Clonidine can be used to help ease the symptoms of opioid withdrawal.
  • It is not an opioid and does not have any addictive properties.
  • However, the withdrawal may not be as painless or rapid as it would be if methadone were used.
  • Blood pressure levels should be monitored when clonidine is used.
  • Naloxone is used to counter the effects of life-threatening depression of the central nervous respiratory systems from opioid (e.g., heroin or methadone) overdose; it would worsen this patient's withdrawal symptoms.

Incorrect options:

Option A- Antabuse or disulfiram is a treatment option for alcoholics, it is not used to treat acute opioid withdrawal.

Option C- Haloperidol, an antipsychotic, has no use in treating withdrawal.

Option D- Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, is commonly used in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal.

questions.text: This syndrome presents with affected individuals being cortically blind but unaware of it and hence deny they have a problem. Patients start falling over furniture as they can't see. However, they believe they can still see and describe their environments in detail but are wrong in their description. Identify this syndrome.
questions.solution:
Anton's syndrome (Anton-Babinski syndrome):

  • Occurs following damage to the occipital lobe.
  • Affected individuals are cortically blind but are unaware of this and deny they have a problem (Anosognosia). It often presents as the patient starts falling over furniture as they can't see. Affected individuals believe they can still see and describe their environments in detail but are wrong in their description (confabulation).

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents with 12-year history of persecutory delusions and hallucinations, along with episodes of bipolarity in between. He was diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder. His relatives would have increased risk for developing most of the following psychiatric disorders except:
questions.solution:
Genetics of Schizoaffective disorder:

  • The risk to first-degree relatives for ANY psychiatric disorder is higher in SA disorder than any other psychiatric disorder. The extent of heritability is unclear, although likely in the range of schizophrenia.
  • Relatives have a higher rate of schizoaffective illness, schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.
  • The rate of bipolar disorder is high if proband has a schizoaffective-manic presentation. The rate of schizophrenia is high if proband has schizoaffective-depressive presentation. In depressive subtype no elevation in bipolar risk has been noted in a large cohort.

Reference: Schizoaffective disorder: MedlinePlus Genetics

questions.text: In a delirious patient, disturbances in attention increase towards the evening time due to sensory deprivation. This is known as:
questions.solution:
In delirious state, the patient becomes more disturbed, disoriented, hyper vigilant towards the evening after sunset due to sensory deprivation.

This is known as sun downing.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with chronic schizophrenia is brought to the emergency room after he is found wandering around his halfway house, confused and disoriented. His serum sodium concentration is 123 mEq/L and urine sodium concentration is 5 mEq/L. The patient has been treated with risperidone 4 mg/day for the past 3 years with good symptom control. His roommate reports that the patient often complains of feeling thirsty. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Self-induced water intoxication should always be considered in the differential diagnosis of confusion states and seizures in schizophrenic patients.

As many as 20% of patients with a diagnosis of schizophrenia drink excessive amounts of water.

At least 4% of these patients suffer from chronic hyponatremia and recurrent acute water intoxication.

Medications that cause excessive water retention, such as Lithium and Carbamazepine, can aggravate the symptomatology.

Reference: Cijo Alex, PGNIP2, Chapter, Page no. 174.

questions.text: A subtype of Schizophrenia with acute onset, cloudiness of consciousness, disorientation, perception disturbance and dreamlike state with rapid shifting is known as?
questions.solution:
• The Oneiroid state refers to a dream like state in which patients may be deeply perplexed and not fully oriented in time and place.
  • The term 'Oneiroid Schizophrenia' has been used for patients who are engaged in their hallucinatory experiences to the exclusion of involvement in the real world.
  • When an Oneiroid state is present, clinicians should be particularly careful to examine patients for medical or neurological causes of symptoms.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old divorced male bus driver was referred for psychiatric consultation for complaints of memory loss for the previous 12 years, behaving and responding to the environment as if it were 12 years previously, e.g., he didn't recognize his 8-year-old son, and denied recollection of current events like name of current president. On mental status examination, the patient displayed intact intellectual function and brain imaging was normal. The patient's mother described a family history of brutal beatings and physical discipline subjected towards the patient.
Pick the correct diagnosis.
questions.solution:
• The above case scenario is suggestive of dissociative amnesia.
  • The main feature of dissociative amnesia is an inability to recall important autobiographical information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature, that is inconsistent with ordinary forgetting.
  • Dissociative amnesia can occur in post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), however other symptoms should be present as well to fulfil the criteria for the same. (Option B)
  • In malingering, there is usually a secondary gain. (Option C)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with agoraphobia was assessed for behavior therapy. Which of the following is she fearful of?
questions.solution: • Agoraphobia is anxiety associated with places or situations either from which escape may be difficult or in which help may not be available in the event of a panic attack. It means literally fear of the crowded place. It is strongly associated with panic. (OPTION B)

questions.text: According to DSM-5, making a determination of severity level of intellectual disability includes assessment of functioning in all of the following domains except:
questions.solution: Making a determination of severity level of intellectual disability, according to DSM-5, includes assessment of functioning in a conceptual domain(e.g., academic skills), a social domain(e.g., relationships) and a practical domain(e.g., personal hygiene).

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman has noted increasing fullness in her neck for the past 3 months. On physical examination, herthyroid gland is diffusely and asymmetrically enlarged. There is no lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound of the neckshowed the presence of nodules malignant. She undergoes thyroidectomy. Gross examination of the thyroid showsnodules and histopathological image is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probablediagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological examination shows nesting pattern of cells along with amyloid deposition.

(a) Branching papillae having a fibrovascular stalk covered by a single to multiple layers of cuboidal epithelial cells. In most neoplasms, the epithelium covering the papillae consists of well-differentiated, uniform, orderly cuboidal cells.

(b) Microscopically, most follicular carcinomas are composed of fairly uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid, quite reminiscent of normal thyroid with capsular and vascular invasion.

(c) Medullary carcinomas are composed of polygonal to spindle-shaped cells, which may form nests, trabeculae, and even follicles.

(d) Anaplastic carcinomas demonstrate variable morphology, including (1) large, pleomorphic giant cells, including occasional osteoclast-like multinucleate giant cells; (2) spindle cells with a sarcomatous appearance; and (3) mixed spindle and giant cells.

questions.text: Decreased ESR is seen in:
questions.solution:
A decreased Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) can be caused by several factors. Here are some of the common causes:

  1. Polycythemia Vera: This is a condition characterized by an increased number of red blood cells
  2. Sickle Cell Disease: This is a genetic disorder that affects the shape and functionality of the red blood cells
  3. Hyperviscosity Syndrome: This is a group of symptoms triggered by an increase in the viscosity of the blood
  4. Hereditary Spherocytosis: This is a condition that leads to an abnormality in the red blood cell membrane, causing the cells to take on a spherical shape
  5. Abetalipoproteinemia and Acanthocytosis: These are rare inherited disorders affecting fat absorption and red blood cell shape

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with a thyroid swelling and dysphagia. He gave history of on and off watery diarrhea. Biopsy of the lesion is shown. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: • Diarrhea in thyroid tumor can be a paraneoplastic syndromes due to VIP in a case of medullary Ca thyroid. Histology demonstrates abundant deposition of amyloid, visible here as homogeneous extracellular material, derived from calcitonin molecules secreted by the neoplastic cells.

questions.text: In a study of hypoglycemic shock, cellular changes in the brain are analyzed. One cell type in the hippocampus is noted to exhibit intense cytoplasmic eosinophilia, central chromatolysis, spheroidal swellings, and nuclear pyknosis. These changes appear 12 hours after blood glucose levels drop below 20 mg/dL. What is this cell type most likely to be:
questions.solution: Hypoxic and hypoglycemic injury leads to "red" neurons as the initial reaction. The larger pyramidal neurons are the most sensitive, particularly in the hippocampus with hypoglycemia, as well as neocortical Betz cells and cerebellar Purkinje cells. Astrocytes proliferate in reaction to brain injury in the process called gliosis. Endothelial cells are most likely to proliferate in neoplasms. Microglia respond to brain injury with a macrophage-like function. Oligodendroglial cells provide myelination for brain neuronal axons.

questions.text: Histological picture of a lesion excised from the right cervical region is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: CASEOUS NECROSIS: Pink in centre, epithelioid cells and langhans giant cells are features of TB

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with history of dyspnea, cough and sputum production. The patient died of respiratory failure. Gross image of lung is shown below. What is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
This image shows Panacinar (panlobular) emphysema.

Panacinar emphysema is associated with α1-antitrypsin deficiency and is exacerbated by smoking. In this type the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli.

In contrast to centriacinar emphysema, panacinar emphysema tends to occur more commonly in the lower zones and in the anterior margins of the lung, and it is usually most severe at the bases.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Histopathology picture of kidney given below. What is not true about the finding in the associated condition?
questions.solution: The history of nephrotic syndrome and blurring of vision. Notice the first image shows Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodule suggestive of Diabetic nephropathy. The histology shows GBM thickening and more permeability.

questions.text: In which infection is the following clinical picture seen?
questions.solution:
'Saxophone penis' is a typical deformity of penis arising secondary to diseases causing chronic lymphatic obstruction in bilateral inguinal region

Secondary lymphedema is predominantly caused in India by filariasis and sexually transmitted infections like lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)

The causative agent of LGV is Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1-L3. It is a lymphotropic organism which initiates the disease process primarily in the lymphatic channels, leading to thrombolymphangitis and perilymphangitis. LGV causes bilateral inguinal bubo in one-third of cases and 'saxophone penis' after LGV is well known.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Clinical Presentation of Psoriasis: Extensor, pressure points

  • Well-demarcated, scaly, silvery, lesions
  • Ring of Woronoff seen
  • Koebner's/Isomorphic phenomenon (lesions at site of trauma)

Nail changes: Thickened nail-plates, Oil-spots/Oil-drop sign, Onycholysis, Thimble-pitting, Subungual hyperkeratosis

  • Grattage test: Accentuation of scales with glass-slide
  • Auspitz sign: Bleeding points on removing membrane

questions.text: All of the following are included in 5'P's of lichen planus except
questions.solution: "Pruritic, Purple, Polygonal, Planar, Papules " are the traditional 5 "P's" of LP

questions.text: A 9-year-old has multiple itchy erythematous wheals all over the body for 2 days. There is no respiratory difficulty. Which is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
• Acute urticaria is a self-limiting disease
  • As the pathophysiology is histamine release, antihistaminic is given

Nonsedating 2nd generation antihistamines are the first-line treatment of urticaria and may be titrated to two to four times their normal dose, if necessary

questions.text: A patient with recurrent lip edema underwent Laboratory evaluation which shows decreased C4 and C1 INH (quantity and function) with normal C1q. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The 3 types of HAE can be differentiated with complement testing and, in the case of HAE with normal C1 inhibitor levels, genetic testing. Type I HAE is characterized by the following:

  • Low C1 esterase inhibitor (C1-INH) protein level
  • Low C4 level
  • Normal C1q level

Type II HAE is characterized by the following:

  • Normal or elevated, but dysfunctional, C1-INH level
  • Low C4 level
  • Normal C1q level

HAE with normal C1 inhibitor levels is characterized by the following:

  • Normal C1-INH level
  • Normal C1-INH functional assay
  • Normal C4 and C1q level
  • Factor XII mutation may be present

questions.text: A patient presented with scarring alopecia. On mucosal examination, lacy white reticulate striae are seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lichen planopilaris is an inflammatory, primaryly lymphocytic cicatricial alopecia. Like lichen planus, the etiology of lichen planopilaris is not known.

The scalp lesions may be single or multiple, focal or diffuse, and occur anywhere on the scalp. Hair follicles around the margins of the bare areas show perifollicular erythema and perifollicular scale, in contrast to discoid lupus erythematosus, where follicular plugging is in the center of the active bare patch.

Cutaneous, nail, and mucous membrane lichen planus may occur before, during, or after the onset of scalp involvement.

The most characteristic trichoscopic feature of active lichen planopilaris is perifollicular scaling.

questions.text: All are true about Langerhan's histiocytosis except?
questions.solution:
Langerhan's Histiocytosis

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is an idiopathic condition characterized by proliferation of abnormal Langerhans cells.

The disease has characteristics of both an abnormal reactive process and a neoplastic process.

LCH can occur at any age but is most common from birth to age 15 years

It may present initially as a rash.

It can be disseminated and involve bone marrow, lungs, liver, spleen, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal (GI) tract, and the pituitary gland.

Prognosis varies depending on presentation and organ involvement.

  • It includes Letterer-Siwe disorder, Hand Schuller Christian disease, Eosinophilic granuloma

choices.text: Possibility of laryngotracheobronchitis should be considered
Flexible bronchoscopy is the procedure of choice
Focal hyperinflation with reduced or absent breath sounds suggests foreign body aspiration
Hyperinflation is often produced by Ball-Valve Mechanism in complete obstruction due to foreign body

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was playing and suddenly developed acute onset breathing difficulty. There is no history of any such symptom in the past or in the family. Chest X Ray showed unilateral hyperinflation of the right lung. What is correct?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset of breathing difficulty in a child and CXR showing unilateral hyperinflation is suggestive of Foreign Body Aspiration.

  • Option A is incorrect. There is no fever, stridor or barking cough to suggest laryngotracheobronchitis.
  • Option B is incorrect. Flexible fiberoptic bronchoscopy is sensitive to visualize but can not be used to remove stuck FB. We always prefer Rigid Bronchoscopy in such patients since it is both diagnostic and therapeutic
  • Option C is correct. Focal hyperinflation in acute distress or reduced breath sounds unilaterally suggest foreign body aspiration
  • Option D is incorrect. Ball valve-mechanism operates in partial obstruction, not complete obstruction. Complete obstruction causes collapse or atelectasis, not hyperinflation.

Also see the following mechanism for more clarity

questions.text:
Sign(s) of heart failure?
A. Non pulsatile elevated JVP
B. Orthopnea
C. Dyspnea occurring after 2 hours of getting bed rest
D. Right upper quadrant pain
questions.solution:
• The JVP in cardiac failure is pulsatile. Option c is suggestive of PND(Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea). Right Upper quadrant pain is suggestive of hepatic congestion. Shortness of breath with activity or when lying down.

Fatigue and weakness, Swelling in the legs, ankles and feet, Rapid or irregular heartbeat, Reduced ability to exercise, Wheezing are some of the signs of Cardiac failure.

questions.text: 50 year-old Labourer becomes unconscious and is brought to ER with temp of 105 F with decreased skin turgor. Which of the following will not be seen?
questions.solution:
The question deals with heat related illness. Our Patient is a relatively young and healthy male who is a manual laborer. He has presented with the temperature of 105 degree F and symptoms of Heatstroke. The type of heat stroke that occurs in young and healthy individuals is Exertional heat stroke, Where the patient will be diaphoretic despite dehydration. Hence, option D is the right answer.

  • The classical triad of a heat stroke are core temperature >40°C, exposure to heat and CNS dysfunction.

There are two types of heat stroke

  1. Classical heat stroke: Occurs in elderly patients with multiple co morbid illness, during periods of heat waves, where they will be exposed to high ambient temperature and humidity for long periods. They are often compliant on medications that impair tolerance to heat stress. Heat dissipation mechanisms are overwhelmed by endogenous heat production, exogenous heat stress and limited access to fluids. The patients will be dry and dehydrated. They have multisystem dysfunction. Hepatocytes are particularly sensitive to heat stress and the levels may reach >100 times the baseline. AKI can occur. DIC likes pictures. Hypernatremia.
  2. Exertional heat stroke: It occurs in young and healthy individuals who are exposed to high temperatures, like manual labourers, military recruits etc. they will be diaphoretic despite dehydration, unlike CHS. They have striking rhabdomyolysis and AKI. They will have hyponatremia and hypoglycemia.

For both EHS and CHS the common findings are myocardial injury called thermal cardiomyopathy. CVP may be elevated despite dehydration. Ards can occur. Tachyarrhythmias can occur. Management of arrhythmias is rapid cooling and not antiarrhythmics.

At a core temperature of >42°C, there will be irreversible damage of all the thermosensitive enzymes. Hence rapid cooling strategies should be initiated.

Prior to initiating cooling ET intubation and continuous core temperature monitoring should be initiated.

Hypoglycemia should be corrected. IV crystalloids should be infused with noradrenaline as there will already be vasoconstriction and impaired heat dissipation.

COOLING STRATEGIES:

  1. EVAPORATIVE COOLING, where cool water 15°C is continuously sprayed over the exposed skin and fan will ensure continuous airflow. Ice packs should be applied to the axilla, groin and neck as adjuncts. Cardiac monitoring is possible by applying electrodes to the back of the patient.
  2. IMMERSION COOLING, by immersing the patient in ice cold Should be tried only in otherwise healthy patients with EHS. Here cardiac monitoring is not possible. Cooling should be stopped once temperature reaches 38-39°C.

Cooling with commercially available cooling blankets is not effective as it takes time to reduce the core temperature. Infusion of cold IV fluids is also not effective.

Fluid resuscitation should be continued despite high CVP as CVP is high due to myocardial injury. Α adrenoreceptor blockers should be avoided as there is already vasoconstriction and further vasoconstriction impairs heat dissipation. If inotropes are needed Dopamine or Dobutamine should be started.

Antipyretics have no role and are detrimental too.

There is no single investigation to confirm the diagnosis of heat stroke. Response to cooling is one method by which we can confirm.

choices.text: Uncuffed tube is better than cuffed tube in a child aged 1 year
A 4 mm size cuffed ET tube is ideal in a 4 year old child
Depth of insertion of ET tube in a 4 year old child should be 14 cm
High cuff pressure >25 cm H20 in a cuffed ETT can cause airway necrosis

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding pediatric intubation, except?
questions.solution:
Let us see all options individually

  • Option A is false. Only in neonates, we prefer an uncuffed tube. Beyond the neonatal period, cuffed tubes are better than uncuffed tubes. They ensure better pressure delivery in patients with poor lung compliance, prevent peritubal leakage and prevent aspirations. Thus a cuffed tube should be used in a child aged 1 year.
