  • Option B is true. For an uncuffed tube, ET tube size (in mm)= (Age in yr/4) + 4. So in a 4 year old child, ideal size of uncuffed tube is 5 mm internal diameter tube. Now, we also know that size of cuffed tube to be taken is always 0.5 to 1 mm less than uncuffed tube. Hence the cuffed ET tube size to be used here will be 5 mm - 1 mm = 4 mm size Cuffed ET Tube
  • Option C is true. Depth of insertion in cm = (Age in yr/2) + 12. So it comes out to be 14 cm in a 4 year old child.
  • Option D is true. Cuff pressure in a cuffed ETT should always be kept below 20 to 25 cm H20 to prevent airway necrosis.

questions.text: An infant presented to pediatric emergency with breathing difficulty, high respiratory rates and scaphoid abdomen with SpO2 of 90% on room air. What should be avoided?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with scaphoid abdomen is consistent with a diagnosis of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • CDH is an absolute contraindication to Bag and Mask Ventilation.
  • Prolonged mask ventilation in the delivery room, which enlarges the stomach and small bowel and thus makes oxygenation more difficult, must be avoided and a naso- or orogastric tube placed immediately for decompression. If distress is severe, intubation can be done.

choices.text: Chronic infarct in the occipital lobe on the left side
Demyelination of the optic nerve of the right eye with multiple demyelinating patches in the brain and the spinal cord
Space occupying lesion in the occipital lobe

questions.text: A 33 year old female comes with a 3 month history of multiple neurological symptoms. It started with a blurring of vision on the right eye. She has noted that the visual blurring increases when she takes a hot shower. She also has multiple episodes of electric shock like sensation radiating from her spine down to both lower limbs. On examination, she has afferent pupillary defect in the right eye, with a pale disc. She also has bilateral lower limb spasticity and hyperreflexia, with extensor plantar response. What will be the likely findings in the MRI of the brain and spinal cord in this patient?
questions.solution:
Lets analyze the symptoms of this young female. She has a blurred vision in the right eye with Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect, which is suggestive of optic neuritis. A pale disc suggests optic atrophy secondary to a long standing optic neuritis. Her visual symptoms increase on taking hot shower. This is known as Uhthoff's Symptoms. Also she has electric shock like sensation that radiates down her spine to both lower limbs. This is known as Lhermitte's symptoms. She has UMN signs in the form of spasticity, hyperreflexia and extensor plantar. All these point to the diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis. The likely MRI finding that we will see will be demyelination of the optic nerve and other demyelinating patches, which may or may not be symptomatic, scattered in the brain and the spinal cord.

SYMPTOMS OF MS:

  • Sensory symptoms, girdle like sensation, pain.
  • Cranial nerve symptoms: Optic neuritis, Facial palsy with sparing of taste sensation in anterior 2/3rdof tongue, gaze disturbances like INO, one and a half syndrome, 6th nerve palsy, pendular nystagmus.
  • Motor symptoms: Weakness and spasticity
  • Ancilliary symptoms: which include Paroxysmal symptoms( brief and self limited neurological symptoms caused by hyperventilation or movement, without any loss of sensorium), Lhermitte's symptoms, Uhthoff's Symptoms, Bilateral trigeminal neuralgia, hemifacial spasm, glossopharyngeal neuralgia, facial myokimia, bladder dysfunction, constipation, fatigue, sexual dysfunction.

IMAGING IN MS:

MRI typically shows areas of hyperintensity in T2 and FLAIR images perpendicular to the ventricles, called Dawson's Fingers. There will be transient enhancement of these lesions on contrast appearance, but the enhancement disappears in one month. The lesion persists life long in MS. >90% of the lesions visualized in the MRI are asymptomatic.

Evoked potentials of the visual, auditory, somatosensory or motor pathways may be abnormal in 80-90% of patients.

CSF oligoclonal bands may be seen in> 90% of cases of MS

questions.text: A patient present with 5 days fever and painful erythematous lesions on face and biopsy revealed neutrophilic infiltrate. What is a most probable diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Neutrophilic dermatoses consist of a group of non-infectious disorders that are characterized by neutrophilic infiltration of the skin (epidermis, dermis, or hypodermis)

Sweet syndrome characteristically demonstrates the sudden onset of well-defined tender plaques or nodules accompanied by fever, arthralgias.

Sweet syndrome may be idiopathic, which is most common, or may be associated with an underlying condition. It may follow:

  1. Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g. ulcerative colitis or Crohn disease)
  2. Rheumatoid arthritis
  3. Myeloproliferative disorders - leukaemia (most often acute myelogenous leukaemia or myelodysplastic syndromes).

In Sweet disease there is a sudden appearance of red tender lumps (plaques) on the skin usually of the limbs or neck, sometimes elsewhere.

DOC - steroids, dapsone, colchicine

questions.text: Nevus simplex commonly presents on:
questions.solution:
Salmon Patch (Nevus Simplex)

MC vascular lesion of infancy

Presents as a flat salmon to pinkish patch that occurs frequently on the posterior neck, around the face and eyelids and glabellar region

These "stork bite" lesions usually fade on the face, but can persists around the orbit or back of the neck

questions.text: A patient gives a h/o recurrent oral ulcers. He also has complains of blurred vision, periorbital pain and photophobia. The most likely diagnosis is-
questions.solution:
Behcet's syndrome-Behcet's syndrome is an disorder of unknown etiology having strong association with HLA B51.

Its more frequently seen in age group 20-30 years having male preponderance.

Clinical features-

Its characterized by recurrent oral and genital aphthous ulcers

Ulcers have a necrotic floor surrounded by halo of erythema.

Other features include erythema nodosum like lesions(which are deep seated multiple tender nodules on shin area)

pathergy test- used for diagnosis of Behcet's syndrome.

Positive results from pathergy skin testing, defined as the formation of a sterile erythematous papule 2 mm in diameter or larger that appears 48 hours following a skin prick with a sharp sterile needle

Fixed drug eruption- well defined round erythematous plaques which sometimes develop central bullae/violaceous hue.They heal leaving behind slate gray hyperpigmentation which persist between acute episodes. Lesions recur at same site each time the offending drug is taken usually after 8-16 hours after intake of drug. Drugs implicated - barbiturates, sulphonamides, tetracyclines, salicylates and phenacetin.

Herpes labialis- It is caused by HSV hominis type1 - closely grouped vesicles which rapidly form polycyclic erosions, on vermilion border of lip.

questions.text: A HIV patient presented with an asymptomatic white lesion on the side of the tongue, which cannot be rubbed off. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Oral hairy leukoplakia, caused by due to Epstein-Barr virus

The image shows a white plaque on side of tongue, with feathery margins and a corrugated surface. The plaque cannot be scraped off, which differentiates it from oral candidiasis.

This is usually an asymptomatic disease.

In a patient of HIV, it usually indicative of fairly advanced immunologic decline, generally occurring in patients with less than 300 CD4+ T cells per microliter.

It responds to HAART.

questions.text: Topical antifungal therapy is the first-line therapy for uncomplicated cases of oral candidiasis. A patient on immunosuppressives develops white lesions on the tongue which cannot be rubbed off. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
• Two important causes of white lesions in a patient - HIV/organ or bone marrow transplant /immunocompromised disease/hematological malignancy
  • Oral hairy leucoplakia - associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), also known as human herpesvirus 4.asymptomatic, unilateral or bilateral non-painful smooth flat, white lesions with irregular "hairy" or "feathery" margins with prominent folds or projections. irregular "hairy" or "feathery" lesion with prominent folds or projections.
    • Seen mostly on the lateral margin of the tongue.
    • The lesion is adherent to the surface and cannot be removed by scraping.
  • Candidiasis: caused by Candida albicans. Asymptomatic, extensive white patches that can be easily removed with gauze, leaving an erythematous mucosa surface.

choices.text: Stunning is a state of depressed myocardial function due to chronic hypoperfusion
Stunning can be global or regional
Myocardial stunning affects both systolic and diastolic function
Oxygen free radicals and excess intracellular calcium likely contribute to stunning

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding myocardial stunning is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Myocardial stunning represents prolonged myocardial dysfunction that follows a brief episode of severe ischemia, with gradual return of contractile activity.

Conversely, Myocardial hibernation is the term applied to myocardial dysfunction resulting from chronic hypoperfusion.

Myocardial stunning affects both systolic and diastolic function and may occur in globally as well as regionally ischemic myocardium. Clinically, stunning is most frequently seen in patients recovering from ischemic arrest during cardiopulmonary bypass.

3 mechanisms of myocardial stunning:

  1. Generation of oxygen-derived free radicals,
  2. Calcium overload, and
  3. Reduced sensitivity of myofilaments to calcium.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old child with a 3-day history of watery diarrhoea and vomiting presented with altered sensorium. Which of the following are differential diagnoses?
1. Severe dehydration
2. HUS
3. Cerebral venous thrombosis
4. Hyponatremia
questions.solution:
Above clinical scenario is suggestive of Acute gastroenteritis of unknown etiology presenting with altered sensorium.

Acute Diarrhoea: Passage of three or more loose stools in 24-hour period and/or a recent change in consistency or character of stool. Acute Watery diarrhoea lasts <7 days up to 14 days without visible blood and the child is prone to dehydration.

Diarrhoea if not treated adequately can lead to fluid deficit and/or electrolyte loss leading to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, acute renal failure, etc.


Patients with cognitive dysfunction can present in the form of altered sensorium, delirium, and convulsion due to severe electrolyte imbalance as well.

  • HUS: Haemolytic Uremic Syndrome is not a complication of dehydration but a clinical syndrome in itself.
  • ETIOLOGY AND EPIDEMIOLOGY: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is characterized by the triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury (AKI).
  • The most common form of HUS is associated with Shiga-toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC) and is termed STEC-HUS.
  • Children with STEC-HUS experience a prodromal diarrheal illness due to hemorrhagic enterocolitis following exposure to a pathogenic agent (most commonly E. coli O157:H7). STEC-HUS outbreaks have been associated with contaminated ground beef, fruit, vegetables, or water. STEC-HUS occurs in ~5-15% of children with STEC infection.
  • Classification based on pathophysiological considerations and triggering factors

Hereditary causes of HUS:

  • Complement gene
  • Inborn errors of cobalamin C metabolism
  • Diacylglycerol kinase epsilon (DGKE) gene mutations

Acquired causes of HUS:

  • Infection:
    • Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC)
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae
    • Human immunodeficiency viral infection
  • Autoantibodies to complement factors
  • Drug toxicity, particularly in patients with cancer or solid organ transplant recipients
  • Rare occurrences in pregnant patients or those with autoimmune disorders (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus)

Clinical course - STEC-HUS typically have a prodromal illness with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea that generally precedes the development of HUS by 3 to 10 days. The diarrhea starts nonbloody and progresses to bloody diarrhea in 60 to 90 percent of cases.

  • Non-STEC-HUS is usually more severe than STEC-HUS and more likely to lead to chronic kidney disease.
  • Less commonly, children may develop a similar microangiopathic syndrome, identified as thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).
  • Children with TTP typically have predominantly central nervous system (CNS) symptoms but may also have significant kidney disease. Because CNS involvement is also seen in HUS, TTP can be difficult to distinguish from HUS.Children with TTP have severe deficiency of ADAMTS13, a von Willebrand factor-cleaving protease.
  • CLINICAL MANIFESTATIONS:
    • STEC-HUS typically occurs in children less than 5 years of age but can occur in older children.
    • Classic STEC-HUS begins with enterocolitis, often with bloody stools, followed in 7-10 days by weakness, lethargy, and oliguria/anuria.
    • Physical examination reveals irritability, pallor, and petechiae. Volume depletion is common at presentations.
    • CNS involvement- up to 25% of cases.
    • Other organ involvement includes pancreatitis, cardiac dysfunction, colonic perforation, etc.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man had a history of myocardial infarction 6 months ago. He had two episodes of syncope and the ECG tracing during one such episode is given below. Coronary angiography showed a 99% LAD artery stenosis and angioplasty was unsuccessful due to the tortuosity of the vessel. Echocardiography shows a dilated LV at 5.9 cm with an ejection fraction of 28%. Which is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
The indications for Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (ICD) include:

  • Patients with a history of sustained VT/VF not due to acute MI or any reversible cause.
  • History of previous MI and EF < 35% for NYHA Class II or III, EF < 30% for Class 1.
  • Familial or inherited condition with predisposition for VT/VF.

questions.text: A 8 year old boy presents with a mild painful swelling over scalp since 3 months. He gives history of having a pet dog at home. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Tinea capitis is an infection of the scalp hair caused by dermatophyte fungi such as Trichophyton and Microsporumspp.
  • Kerion is a severe inflammatory form of tinea capitis with a hypersensitivity reaction against dermatophytes.
  • Kerion is usually associated with infection by zoophilic dermatophytes,
  • Red boggy swelling, mildly/non tender, studded with pustules, easy pluckability of hair, regional lymphadenopathy - Kerion
  • IOX: KOH scraping
  • TOC: Griseofulvin

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A boil, also known as a furuncle, is a bacterial infection involving the hair follicle and perifollicular tissue.

It appears as a painful red swelling around the follicular opening and may progress to form an abscess.

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is secreted by which of the following?
A. Liver
B. Kidney
C. Muscle
D. Heart
questions.solution:
The correct answer is d. Only B

Erythropoietin (EPO) is primarily secreted by the kidneys, specifically by the peritubular capillary endothelial cells in the renal cortex and outer medulla.

A. Liver

While the liver can produce small amounts of EPO, it is not the main source of this hormone. The kidneys are responsible for the majority of EPO production.

C. Muscle

Muscle tissue does not secrete erythropoietin.

D. Heart

The heart is also not a site of EPO production

questions.text: A known case of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease and hypertension was under therapy with Enalapril. On follow up, his HbA1c was elevated (8.5%). Which of the following drugs should be used with caution in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, where a patient with COPD and hypertension is on Enalapril and has developed an elevated HbA1c (8.5%), the drug that should be used with caution is a. Metformin.

Rationale

Metformin is generally the first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes; however, it should be used with caution in patients who are on medications that can affect renal function or in those who may be at risk for lactic acidosis. Although the search results indicate that Enalapril can be safely co-administered with Metformin, the caution arises from the fact that both drugs can impact renal function, especially in patients with existing conditions like COPD, which may complicate their overall health status.

Glimepiride (option b) is a sulfonylurea that can cause hypoglycemia but does not have the same renal considerations as Metformin.

Acarbose (option c) is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that works in the intestines and does not significantly interact with Enalapril.

Sitagliptin (option d) is a DPP-4 inhibitor that is generally well-tolerated and does not have significant interactions with Enalapril.

While the search results indicate that Metformin can be safely used with Enalapril, the caution is warranted due to potential renal implications and the risk of lactic acidosis, especially in a patient with compromised pulmonary function. Therefore, the best answer is a. Metformin.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2847668/

questions.text:
Which of the following statements matches the diagnosis of acute respiratory distress in a child?
1) Within 7 days of known insult
2) Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or LV dysfunction
3) New Chest Infiltrates
4) PaO2/FiO2: 100-200 mm Hg
questions.solution:
The criteria listed match the definition of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), which includes:

Within 7 days of a known insult: ARDS typically develops within 7 days of the inciting event (e.g., pneumonia, trauma, aspiration).

Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or LV dysfunction: This indicates that ARDS is primarily a pulmonary issue, not due to heart failure.

New chest infiltrates: Chest X-ray or CT shows new, bilateral infiltrates indicative of ARDS.

PaO2/FiO2: 100-200 mm Hg: This range falls within the classification of moderate ARDS, based on the PaO2/FiO2 ratio.

Thus, all the given points are correct and align with the diagnostic criteria for ARDS in children.

Key takeaways:-Paediatric ARDS guideline

11111

questions.text: Which of the following event occur during phase B to rise body temperature to hypothalamus set point?
questions.solution:
The anterior hypothalamus compares the detected core temperature to the set-point temperature.

  • If the core temperature is below the set point, heat-generating mechanisms (e.g., increased metabolism, shivering, vasoconstriction of cutaneous blood vessels) are activated by the posterior hypothalamus.
  • If the core temperature is above the set point, mechanisms for heat loss (e.g., vasodilation of the cutaneous blood vessels, increased sympathetic outflow to the sweat glands) are activated by the anterior hypothalamus.

questions.text: The reflex in which there is inhibition of gastric emptying when there is acid or hypertonic solution in the duodenum
questions.solution:
Enterogastric Inhibition irritation of duodenal mucosa causes initiation of Enterogastric Reflex that delays gastric emptying.

Other Factors decreasing gastric Emptying are

  1. Duodenal Distension
  2. Irritation of Duodenal Mucosa
  3. Acidic chyme
  4. Hyperosmolar Chyme
  5. High Fat content of Chyme.

choices.text: Axons Carry impulses away from cell body
Axon does not contain nissl granules

questions.text: True about Axons of nerve cell is
questions.solution:
• Nerve cell is divided in to cell body and processes (dendrites and axons)
  • Characteristics of the axons are
  • Each neuron has only one axon
  • Arises from axon hillock of soma
  • Carry impulses away from cell body (dendrites carry towards the cell body)
  • Cannot synthesize own protein depends upon soma
  • Contain granules or vesicles which contain synaptic transmitters (dendrites do not have it)
  • Specialized to convert electrical signal (AP) to chemical signal (Dendrites generate local potentials only)

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male had a party on Saturday night. He was overly drunk that night. On Sunday morning as he got up he had paralysis in one arm. It occurred due to compression of which fibers from the following?
questions.solution:
• The various types of a fibers react to different kinds of factors (pressure, hypoxia, local anesthetics) differently.
  • Type C fibers are most susceptible to local anesthetic before it affects other types of fibers.
  • Type B fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than other types of fibers.
  • Type A fibers are more susceptible to sustained pressure than other types of fibers.
  • As above, the patient was over drunk and slept. Due to deep sleep he was not aware about sleeping the whole night while his hand was under his head. So constant pressure compressed his nerves. But type A fibers are most susceptible to pressure so he had paralysis (type A fibers are motor, touch and pressure fibers).

Key Takeaway: IN PRESSURE the order of susceptibility is type A>B>C.

In hypoxia the order of susceptibility is Type B>A>C.

questions.text: Following is a particular recording in EEG study. The frequency of the wave is 14 per second. It has a lower voltage. The recordings are from parietal areas. This recording is obtained during
questions.solution:
• In EEG recording four different types of waves are obtained, they are alpha, beta, theta and delta.
  • Above mentioned waves are beta waves best obtained from the parietal area and frontal area in alert and wakeful person.
  • Alpha waves are obtained during the quiet and wakeful stage of sleep and wakefulness.
  • Theta waves are recorded in emotional stress and degenerative brain disorders.
  • Delta waves are recorded in case of organic brain disorders.

Key Takeaway: Beta Waves

  • Frequency: 13-30 Hz
  • State of Consciousness: Alert, focused, and engaged in mental activity.
  • Associated with: Problem-solving, decision-making, and intense concentration.

questions.text: In the learning process we try to recall words with the help of the 1st few letters of it. Suppose a 6 year old child tries to recall the spelling of 'ELEPHANT'. The teacher helps the child to recall the spelling by saying 1st few letters as 'ELE'. This type of memory recall is known as
questions.solution:
• Memory can be divided in explicit and implicit form.
  • Types of implicit memory
  • Priming is the improved recall of a word when presented with the first few letters of it. It is a function of the neocortex.
  • Procedural memory (skills, habits) once acquired become automatic.
  • Conditioning is learning of the relationship between stimuli. IT is a type of associative learning.
  • Sensitization is a type of non-associative learning dependent on reflex pathways.

Key Takeaway: Priming is the improved recall of a word when presented with the first few letters of it. It is a function of the neocortex.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has hyperpigmentation & found to have SMR stage 5. His Height age is exceeding the chronological age & is also hypertensive, with BP of 180/120 mm of Hg. Likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
At 10 yr age SMR stage 5(Puberty completed), Height age>Chronological age these are suggestive of precocious puberty.

Hypertensive(180/120 mm of Hg): Salt retaining crisis

Male child

Normal genitalia

Then most likely enzyme deficiency will be 11-hydroxylase deficiency.

Approach to diagnosis in CAH


Explanation of Incorrect Choices:

  1. Choice A. 21-hydroxylase deficiency:
    • This is the most common cause of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH), but it typically results in salt-wasting crisis (due to lack of aldosterone) and virilization. It may cause hypotension and hypoglycemia, which doesn't match the hypertension seen in this case. It can also cause hypertrophy of external genitaliain females, but not in males with normal genitalia.
  2. Choice C. 3-Beta hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency:
    • This enzyme deficiency causes a severe form of CAH that leads to defects in cortisol, aldosterone, and sex steroid synthesis. It generally results in ambiguous genitalia in both males and females and salt-wasting crises, which is not seen here with normal male genitalia and the presence of hypertension.
  3. Choice D. Cholesterol side-chain cleavage enzyme deficiency:
    • This is a rare cause of CAH where the cholesterol side-chain cleavage enzyme is deficient, leading to a block in steroid hormone production. This typically results in severe symptoms, including virilization and salt-wasting, but it is not typically associated with isolated hypertension and the normal genitalia observed in this case.

Key Takeaways:

  • 11-beta hydroxylase deficiency leads to excessive androgens and 11-deoxycorticosterone, which causes precocious puberty and hypertension (salt-retaining crisis).
  • Hyperpigmentation in this case is likely due to the elevated ACTH levels resulting from low cortisol production.
  • 21-hydroxylase deficiency and other CAH disorders can cause different manifestations like salt-wasting and ambiguous genitalia, but 11-beta hydroxylase deficiency best fits the clinical picture.

Negative electrode is applied on the Right arm
Positive electrode is applied on the left arm

questions.text: True about lead III in bipolar limb leads is
questions.solution:
• Standard limb leads are bipolar limb leads I, II, III.
  • Bipolar limb leads record potential difference between two limbs.
  • Current flows only in the body fluids, the records obtained are those that would be obtained if the electrodes were at the points of attachment of the limbs at any point in the limb.
  • Lead l. Negative terminal of the electrocardiograph is connected to the right arm and positive terminal to the left arm.
  • Lead II. The negative terminal of the electrocardiograph is connected to the right arm and positive terminal to the left leg.
  • Lead III. The negative terminal of the electrocardiograph is connected to the left arm and the positive terminal to the left leg.

KeyTakeaway:

choices.text: To remove build up of lactic acid in the muscles
To replace the store oxygen which is used during exercise

questions.text: The body normally contains about 2 liters of stored oxygen that can be used for aerobic metabolism even without breathing any new oxygen. In addition, about 9 liters more oxygen must be consumed to reconstitute the phosphagen system and the lactic acid system. After heavy exercise the amount of oxygen that is required to replenish the store oxygen is called oxygen debt. What is the primary cause of oxygen debt in the later portion of recovery?
questions.solution:
• In heavy exercise, almost all this stored oxygen is used within a minute or so for aerobic metabolism.
  • After the exercise is over, this stored oxygen must be replenished by breathing extra amounts of oxygen over and above the normal requirements.
  • In addition, about 9 liters more oxygen must be consumed to reconstitute the phosphagen system and the lactic acid system. All this extra oxygen that must be "repaid", about 11.5 liters, is called the oxygen debt.
  • After the exercise is over, the oxygen uptake still remains above normal; at first it is very high while the body is reconstituting the phosphagen system.
  • Later on still oxygen debt is there to recover from lactic acid removal.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • After the exercise is over, the oxygen uptake still remains above normal; at first it is very high while the body is reconstituting the phosphagen system.
  • Later on still oxygen debt is there to recover from lactic acid removal.

questions.text: A 41-year-old male presented to the doctor with involuntary muscle contractions and muscle cramps. On evaluation the patient is found to have tetany. Doctor also observed that the patient has acid base imbalance. Probable acid base imbalance is
questions.solution:
• Tetany occurs due to hypocalcemia leading to muscle cramps and involuntary contractions.
  • Alkalosis can lead to decreased ionized calcium levels in the blood, even if total calcium levels remain normal. Reduction in ionized calcium can increase neuromuscular irritability, contributing to tetany.
  • In alkalosis, an increase of alkalis in the body will bind to the ionic calcium ion and cause fall in ionized calcium level producing the symptoms of tetany.
  • In acidosis plasma calcium level does not fall directly. So the chances of Tetany is not possible

KeyTakeaway:

  • In alkalosis, an increase of alkalis in the body will bind to the ionic calcium ion and cause fall in ionized calcium level producing the symptoms of tetany.

questions.text: In exercising muscles, the primary cause of increase in blood flow to the skeletal muscle is
questions.solution:
• Sympathetic activation in exercise causes an increase in stroke volume and heart rate to increase blood flow. It is a generalized response. It does not provide local vasodilatation.
  • Baroreceptors are the receptors that detect the pressure changes and they respond to increase in blood pressure. During exercise their activity is decreased to increase in blood pressure.
  • In exercising muscles due to metabolism there is accumulation of local metabolites like lactic acid, CO2. It causes a decrease in total peripheral resistance.
  • Tachycardia occurs during exercise which increases overall blood flow but not local to the muscles.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • In exercising muscles due to metabolism there is accumulation of local metabolites like lactic acid, CO2.
  • It causes a decrease in total peripheral resistance.

choices.text: Erythropoietin can be produced by liver
Norepinephrine and epinephrine stimulates the production of erythropoietin
Hypoxia inducible factor 1 stimulates the production of erythropoietin

questions.text: True about erythropoietin is
questions.solution:
• Erythropoietin is produced by the kidney, but 10 % of it is produced in the liver also.
  • Erythropoietin stimulates overall steps of erythropoiesis.
  • Hypoxia inducible factor 1 is the transcription factor for hypoxia inducible genes including erythropoietin gene. Hypoxia response element in the erythropoietin gene, inducing transcription of messenger RNA and, ultimately, increased erythropoietin synthesis.
  • Hypoxia in other parts of the body also stimulates erythropoietin production. In particular, norepinephrine and epinephrine and several of the prostaglandins stimulate erythropoietin production.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: Identify the hazards of mismatched blood transfusion from the following list.
questions.solution:
• Transfusion of blood leads to some hazards in the recipient. It can be either hazard due to mismatched transfusion. Sometimes it may occur even after matched blood transfusion.
  • Hazard of mismatched transfusion are
    • Excessive hemolysis ( breakdown of RBCs)
    • Hemolytic jaundice (Excessive bilirubin formation)
    • Acute renal failure (due to Hb crystals)
    • Hepatic coma
    • Circulatory shock
  • Hazards even after matched transfusion
    • Circulatory overload
    • Transmission of blood borne infection
    • Pyrogenic reaction
    • Allergic reaction
    • Hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
    • Reduced tissue oxygenation due to reduced 2,3 DPG
    • Hemosiderosis
    • Thrombophlebitis
    • Air embolism

Key Takeaway:

  • Hazard of mismatched transfusion are
    • Excessive hemolysis ( breakdown of RBCs)
    • Hemolytic jaundice (Excessive bilirubin formation)
    • Acute renal failure (due to Hb crystals)
    • Hepatic coma
    • Circulatory shock

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was evaluated by a pediatrician for weakness and easy fatigability. On investigation the doctor identified that the patient has a defect in the beta chain. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The hemoglobinopathies are inherited type of hemoglobin disorders, in which there is abnormality in the globin chain.
  • Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy in which abnormal globin polypeptide chains are produced (alpha or beta).
  • Another hemoglobinopathy is sickle cell anemia in which the beta chain is defective because of single substitution of a valine residue for one glutamic acid. Here RBCs become sickle shaped when exposed to hypoxia.
  • In Methemoglobinemia fe++ ion is replaced by Fe+++, that reduces the affinity of oxygen with hemoglobin producing anemia.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: A 49-year-old hypothyroid female visited the endocrinologist for a checkup. The doctor investigated her and found that the patient does not respond to TSH. It is probably
questions.solution:
• Hypothyroidism can be divided into primary and secondary hypothyroidism.
  • Primary hypothyroidism occurs due to abnormality in the thyroid gland in the patient.
  • Secondary hypothyroidism occurs due to abnormality of pituitary (decrease in TSH) or abnormality in hypothalamus (decreased TRH) in the patient.
  • In secondary hypothyroidism thyroid gland responds to TSH level. Patient can be treated with administration of TSH.
  • In primary hypothyroidism production of thyroid hormone does not occur despite TSH administration as thyroid is abnormal.

KEY TAKE AWAY

  • Primary hypothyroidism occurs due to abnormality in the thyroid gland in the patient.
  • Secondary hypothyroidism occurs due to abnormality of pituitary (decrease in TSH) or abnormality in hypothalamus (decreased TRH) in the patient.

questions.text: Urea transport protein UT is of different varieties. UT B is not found in
questions.solution:
• Urea helps in establishment of osmotic gradients in the medullary pyramids. It also helps in the collecting duct to form concentrated urine.
  • Urea transport occurs by facilitated diffusion by urea transports.
    • Types : UT A (1 to 4)
    • In collecting ducts there is UT A1 and UT A3.
    • Both are regulated by vasopressin hormone.
    • During antidiuresis, when vasopressin is high, the amount of urea deposited in the medullary interstitium.
  • UT-B is found in erythrocytes and in the descending limbs of the vasa recta.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: Which of the following substance administration in large quantities does not inhibit the vasopressin secretion but produces osmotic diuresis?
questions.solution:
• Osmotic diuresis is increased production and excretion of urine due to the presence of certain substances in the renal tubules that cannot be reabsorbed efficiently.
  • Large amount of mannitol acts as an osmotic substance and produces osmotic diuresis.
  • Administration of ethanol inhibits secretion of vasopressin to produce diuresis.
  • Large amounts of water administration reduces the plasma osmolarity causing the hypothalamus to identify the low osmolarity which in turn inhibits the vasopressin (ADH) secretion.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: Identify the given structure
questions.solution:
The Islets of Langerhans are clusters of endocrine cells dispersed within the exocrine pancreas.These clusters appear as lighter-staining regions compared to the surrounding darker-staining pancreatic acini.

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice A): Lymph Node- capsule, lymphoid follicles in cortex, medulla.

(Choice B): Glomeruli- Tuft of capillaries surrounded by Bowman's capsule, seen in the renal cortex.

(Choice C): Demilune - demilunes are half-moon shaped formations of serous cells in some salivary glands.

The histology confirms it is an Islet of Langerhans, making this incorrect.

Key takeaway: The Islets of Langerhans are clusters of endocrine cells dispersed within the exocrine pancreas

questions.text: Where is the defect in multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple sclerosis is a disorder of the CNS characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination and scarring.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system (CNS) characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (plaques or scarring), and neuronal loss; the course can be relapsing or progressive.

MS plaques typically develop at different times and in different CNS locations (i.e., MS is said to be disseminated in time and space).

Demyelination New MS lesions begin with perivenular cuffing by inflammatory mononuclear cells, predominantly T cells and macrophages, which also infiltrate the surrounding white matter.

At sites of inflammation, the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is disrupted, but unlike in vasculitis, the vessel wall is preserved.

At the leading edge of lesions, large numbers of cytotoxic CD8 cells are found. Involvement of the humoral immune system is also evident; small numbers of B lymphocytes infiltrate the nervous system, myelin-specific autoantibodies are present on degenerating myelin sheaths, and complement is activated.

questions.text: An 82-year-old patient with hypertension comes with acute onset of breathlessness. Chest x-ray is shown below. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
Nitroglycerin is a vasodilator commonly used to manage acute pulmonary edema secondary to hypertension. By dilating blood vessels, it reduces preload and afterload on the heart, thereby decreasing the work of the heart and improving cardiac output. This can help alleviate pulmonary congestion and edema. Therefore, IV nitroglycerin is often considered the treatment of choice for acute pulmonary edema associated with hypertension.

Other CXR findings include:

  • Upper lobe venous congestion,
  • Thickened interlobular septum,
  • Interstitial edema,
  • Kerley B lines. Once PCWP is elevated to moderate or severe levels

A. Oxygen + Antibiotics:While oxygen therapy is crucial for maintaining adequate oxygenation in patients with pulmonary edema, antibiotics are not typically indicated unless there is a concurrent infection. Antibiotics would not directly address the acute pulmonary edema associated with hypertension.

B. Intravenous Salbutamol (Albuterol):Salbutamol is a bronchodilator commonly used in conditions such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). While it may help alleviate some symptoms associated with pulmonary edema by reducing bronchospasm, it is not the primary treatment for acute pulmonary edema.

D. Nebulized Salbutamol (Albuterol):Nebulized salbutamol is similar to intravenous salbutamol in its mechanism of action as a bronchodilator. While it may provide some relief for respiratory symptoms, it is not the primary treatment for acute pulmonary edema.

choices.text: Ventricular diastole when the tricuspid valve is open
Ventricular diastole when the tricuspid valve is closed
Bulging of the tricuspid value into the right atrium

questions.text: C wave in JVP is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
a wave

  • represents atrial systole, occurs along with S4, preceeding theS1.
  • a wave will be hence absent in atrial fibrillation.
  • A prominent wave will be seen when the atria contracts against a non compliant right ventricle.
  • Canon a wave occurs in AV dissociation, where the atria contracts against a closed ventricle, as in Ventricular tachycardia.

X descent indicates a fall in the right atrial pressure, after the atrial systole. During this time, the tricuspid valves close and the valve is pushed into the atria, resulting in a small positive c wave, which interrupts the x descent. Hence it correlated with S1.

Immediately after the closure of the tricuspid valve, the ventricular systole begins, during which time, the atria is relaxed and the atrial filling takes place.

The atrial filling is represented by the v wave in JVP. When the filling of the atria is increased the v wave will be accentuated.

In tricuspid regurgitation, the tricuspid valves fail to close properly hence the c wave will merge with the v wave to form a giant v wave or the v wave is ventricularized.

They descent indicates the rapid filling of the ventricles. In tricuspid regurgitation, they decent will be rapid. In conditions where the RV compliance is reduced or the tricuspid valve is stenosed, they decent will be prolonged.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient from Chattisgarh having progressive motor symptoms and leg cramps for 1 month. What history will you enquire for making a diagnosis?

questions.text: A neonate was born through normal vaginal delivery at term. His birth weight was 3.8 Kg and was plotted on the chart in red, as shown in the figure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As seen in the image, the birth weight of the neonate has been plotted on the Lubchenco's Chart & since it is above 90th percentile, the diagnosis is Large for gestational age, LGA Baby. Also note that since the birth weight is <4 Kg, the baby is not having macrosomia.



  • Classification of neonates based upon centiles/charts (e.g., Lubchenco's or Fenton's Charts)- We take BW, Gest Age & then plot on a chart.
  • Interpretation
    1. Appropriate for gestational age (AGA): Between 10th to 90th centiles
    2. Small for gest age (SGA): Below 10th centile
    3. Large of gest age (LGA): Above 90th centile

Classification Of Neonates Based upon birth weight (BW)

i. Normal BW: 2.5 to 3.99 kg

ii. Low Birth Weight (LBW): Below 2.5 kg

iii. Very Low Birth Weight (VLBW): Below 1.5 kg

iv. Extremely Low Birth Weight (ELBW): Below 1 kg

v. Macrosomia: 4 kg or above

questions.text: A neonate with erythematous papules with few yellow-white lesions appearing on trunk day 2 of life and disappearing in 4 days. The baby is otherwise healthy and normal. Likely Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A benign, self-limited, evanescent eruption, erythema toxicum occurs in approximately 50% of full-term infants; preterm infants are affected less commonly.
  • The lesions are firm, yellow-white, 1-2 mm papules or pustules with a surrounding erythematous flare. At times, splotchy erythema is the only manifestation.
  • The palms and soles are usually spared. Peak incidence occurs on the 2nd day of life, and usually resolve within one week.
  • Onset may occasionally be delayed for a few days to weeks in premature infants.
  • Eosinophils can be demonstrated in Wright-stained smears of the intralesional contents.
  • Cultures are sterile.

Regarding other options, they are also benign lesions

  • Option B- Mongolian Spots present as blue-black macules on buttocks and posterior aspects of the neonate
  • Option C- Transient Pustular Melanosis presents as multiple pustules grouped on an underlying melanotic, hyperpigmented patch of skin
  • Option D- Sebaceous hyperplasia can present as yellow-white papules on the face and cheek of the neonates.

questions.text: Look at the image and identify the associated genetic abnormality.
questions.solution:
The picture is showing a single transverse palmar crease, also known as simian crease. This physical finding is often seen in children with Down syndrome, also known as Trisomy 21.


Among the options given, option D suggests a male child with Trisomy 21 and is thus the answer.

questions.text: You are formulating a differential diagnosis for a newborn infant with respiratory distress. Which of the following is MOST closely associated with the development of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (hyaline membrane disease)?
questions.solution:
• Prematurity is the strongest predisposing factor to surfactant deficiency disease or respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).


  • While low birth weight infants are also at risk, the risk is more related to the gestational age of the infant.
  • Maternal diabetes does predispose newborns to RDS by causing delayed surfactant release compared to infants of comparable gestational age, but is not as strong of a risk as prematurity itself.
  • Cesarean delivery predisposes more to a condition known as transient tachypnea of the newborn, related to excessive fluid retention within the lungs.

  • Meconium in the amniotic fluid may cause respiratory disease if aspirated into the infant's lungs but the pathophysiology of the disease differs from RDS.

questions.text: All of the following are phagocytic disorders except?
questions.solution:
Ataxia Telangiectasia is considered to be a type of Combined B and T cell defect.

All others are examples of phagocytic disorders. For details, kindly refer to the detailed classification flow-chart discussed in the Doctutorials Pediatrics Video Lectures.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male child with recurrent sinusitis is found to have a normal WBC count but no circulating B cells, small tonsils, and no palpable lymph nodes. Serum concentrations of IgG, IgA, IgM, and IgE are below the 95% lower limits for age. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Clues in the question

  • Recurrent infections in a male child
  • No circulating B-Cells, Small tonsils and no LNs
  • All classes of immunoglobulins are reduced uniformly

All this suggests the X-linked recessive disorder, called X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

Patients with X-linked agammaglobulinemic (XLA), or Bruton's agammaglobulinemia, have a profound defect in B-lymphocyte development resulting in severe; hypogammaglobinaemia, an absence of circulating B cells, small to absent tonsils, and no palpable lymph nodes.

questions.text: A newborn female develops jaundice at 12 hours of life. Her indirect bilirubin is 21.2 mg/dL. Her mother's blood type is AB+; her blood type is A+. Her direct Coombs test is negative. Her CBC shows WBC 15,200/cumm, Hb 10 g/dL, Hct 30%, MCV 98 fL, MCHC 37 g/dL, Platelets 2.75 lac/cumm. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The patient is a newborn with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and low Hb for a neonate.

  • This patient's jaundice is not consistent with physiologic jaundice given the elevated bilirubin level within the first 24 hours of life. In this setting, with an MCHC of greater than 36 g/dL, the most likely diagnosis is hereditary spherocytosis in the newborn period. The likely diagnosis is hereditary spherocytosis, which can be confirmed by osmotic fragility testing.
  • Outside the newborn period this disease typically presents as intermittent jaundice and palpable splenomegaly.
  • Neonates with G6PD deficiency can also present with non-physiologic jaundice; however, G6PD deficiency is X-linked and this patient is a female. In addition, the MCHC is normal in patients with G6PD.
  • Hb Electrophoresis will pick Thalassemia and Sickle Cell anemias and similar hemoglobinopathies which are unlikely to present in this age group.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with abdominal pain which was acute in nature, vomiting and progressive lethargy. There was red-currant jelly stools and contrast enema revealed coiled spring sign. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In typical cases of intussusception, there is sudden onset, in a previously well child, of severe paroxysmal colicky pain that recurs at frequent intervals and is accompanied by straining efforts with legs and knees flexed and loud cries.

  • At times, the lethargy is disproportionate to the abdominal signs. Eventually, a shock-like state, with fever and peritonitis, can develop.
  • Vomiting occurs in most cases and is usually more frequent in the early phase. In the later phase, the vomitus becomes bile stained.
  • 60% of infants pass a stool containing red blood and mucus, the currant jelly stool.
  • The diagnostic findings of intussusception on ultrasound include a tubular mass in longitudinal views and a doughnut or target appearance in transverse images.
  • Contrast enemas demonstrate a filling defect or cupping in the head of the contrast media where its advance is obstructed by the intussusceptum.
  • A central linear column of contrast media may be visible in the compressed lumen of the intussusceptum, and a thin rim of contrast may be seen trapped around the invaginating intestine in the folds of mucosa within the intussuscipiens (coiled-spring sign), especially after evacuation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with an increased risk of future epilepsy in a child with febrile seizures?
questions.solution: Early age of onset <1 yr is a risk factor, not late age of onset. Also note the following risk factors for future epilepsy. These are different from risk factors for recurrence.

questions.text: I am a pediatric malignancy. I often afflict young children & can produce lung, lymph node and liver metastases. FNAC & Blind Biopsy is not recommended in me. I respond well to chemotherapy with Vincristine, Actinomycin-D and Doxorubicin. Who am I?
questions.solution:
Clues to the diagnosis of Wilms Tumour here.

  • Clue 1- Pediatric malignancy in young children. Wilms tumour occurs in children aged 2-3 years.
  • Clue 2- Metastases to lung, lymph nodes and liver is seen in Wilms tumour
  • Clue 3- Blind biopsy is avoided since it can upstage the disease, as per Nelson 21st Imaging studies include plain abdominal radiography, abdominal ultrasonography (US), and CT of the abdomen to define the intrarenal origin of the mass and differentiate it from adrenal masses (e.g., neuroblastoma) and other masses in the abdomen.
  • Clue 4- Responds to chemotherapy with Vincristine, Actinomycin-D and Doxorubicin- Seen in Wilms Tumour. After radical nephrectomy, most patients receive chemotherapy using the said agents.

questions.text: A 60 year old man presents with severe pain in his left loin radiating to the left groin. Bedside testing of urine demonstrates haematuria. Abdominal ultrasound does not demonstrate any abnormality and X-ray KUB does not show any visible stones. Which form of calculus might the patient have?

questions.text: During his 1st physical examination following birth at home with the assistance of a midwife, a 5- week-old male is suspected to have congenital hypothyroidism. His parents refused all newborn screening at the time of his birth. Which of the following may be the earliest clinical sign of congenital hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:

  • Poor feeding, partly due to a large tongue, somnolence, and lack of interest are characteristic.
  • Additional clinical findings may include a large protuberant abdomen; umbilical hernia; mottled, cool, and dry skin; extremity edema; and widely open fontanelles.

questions.text: Most common cause of empyema in a child aged 2 years is?

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of empyema in young children upto 2 to 3 yr of age. In older children Strep pyogenes is more common.

Also note the criteria to define empyema

Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) Clinical features:

Kartagener Syndrome is characterized by a triad of

Please note that Kartagener Syndrome occurs in about 50% patients with Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia.

questions.text: Cleft like space in atheromatous plaque mainly contains?
questions.solution: Cholesterol clefts: Space caused by the dissolving out of cholesterol crystals in sections of tissue embedded in paraffin.

choices.text: Reduced urinary excretion of potassium and chloride

questions.text: Which one of the following features is characteristic of Bartter's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Bartter's syndrome is a childhood disease inherited as an autosomal recessive trait. Pathophysiology impaired loop sodium NaK2Cl reabsorption leads to increased renin and aldosterone secretion with juxtaglomerular hyperplasia. Enhanced sodium-chloride delivery to the collecting duct stimulates potassium secretion leading to hypokalemia. It also causes hydrogen ion secretion resulting in metabolic alkalosis. Accelerated kinin and prostaglandins secretion may account for the vascular unresponsiveness to the pressor effect. This explains the absence of increase in blood pressure and oedema despite the elevated levels of renin and aldosterone. Indomethacin inhibits prostaglandin and restores normal physiological vascular response.

Hypokalemia with hypertension is seen with disorders that are related to the ENaC Conn's Syndrome, Liddle syndrome.

Bartter's syndrome is associated with increased urinary excretion of potassium and chloride.

IN Bartter's syndrome, the addition of Spironolactone, Amiloride or ACE inhibitors improves hypokalemia, but worsens the hypovolemia. NSAIDS may be useful in Bartter's syndrome, as they inhibit the tubuloglomerular feedback. Potassium supplementation and liberal salt intake should be given.

Gitelman syndrome also should be treated similarly, but NSAIDS have no role.

questions.text: Which of the following pigment is called the 'wear and tear' pigment?
questions.solution: Lipofuscin pigment is called as the "wear and tear" pigment

questions.text: All of the following are true for TGF-beta except:
questions.solution: TGF-beta is an anti-inflammatory, it inhibits collagen degradation, also drives fibrosis in lung, liver and kidneys in the setting of chronic inflammation and act as a tumor suppressor gene.

questions.text: A Short stature girl child complaints of amenorrhea. On examination, she had broad chest, widely spaced nipples, cubitus valgus and pigmented nevi. Karyotyping was performed revealing 45, X karyotype. What can be the diagnosis?
Which of the following antimuscarinic agent is approved to use in COPD?
questions.solution:
• Ipratropium appears to be at least as effective in patients with COPD that includes a partially reversible component.
  • A longer acting, selective antimuscarinic agent, tiotropium, is approved as a treatment for COPD.

questions.text: Single amino acid replacement of glutamine with valine on the hemoglobin β Chain seen in sickle cell disease. What is true about this statement
questions.solution:
• Sickle cell anemia is caused by a missense single amino acid substitution in β-globin that results in a tendency for deoxygenated HbS to self-associate into polymers. Normal hemoglobins are tetramers composed of two pairs of similar chains. smear shows sickle cells not schistocytes
  • On average, the normal adult red cell contains 96% HbA (α2β2), 3% HbA2 (α2δ2), and 1% fetal Hb (HbF, α2γ2). In patients with sickle cell anemia, HbA is completely replaced by HbS, whereas in heterozygous carriers, only about half is replaced. HbS differs from HbA by having a valine residue instead of a glutamate residue at the 6th amino acid position in β-globin.
  • On deoxygenation HbS molecules undergo a conformational change that allows polymers to form via intermolecular contacts involving the abnormal valine residue. These polymers distort the red cell, which assumes an elongated crescentic, or sickle, shape.
  • Hereditary spherocytosis is confirmed by increased osmotic fragility test. Spherocytosis show increased osmotic fragility when placed in hypotonic salt solutions, a characteristic that can help establish the diagnosis. Sickle cells show decreased osmotic fragility.

questions.text: A 33-year-old Caucasian male is seen in the emergency department for pain and redness of the right buttock. He is started on trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and doxycycline. He returns to his family physician four days later because of a yellowing of his eyes. His physical examination is unremarkable except for mild jaundice and scleral icterus. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 10.2 x 109 cells/L, a hemoglobin of 7.2 g/dL, and a platelet count of 260 x 109 cells/L. Total bilirubin is 6.2 mg/dL and direct bilirubin is 0.3 mg/dL. Amino transferases are normal. Serum haptoglobin is undetectable. A peripheral blood smear is likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The onset of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and anemia after exposure to sulfamethoxazole is highly suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Pencil cells would be expected in iron deficiency anemia.
  • Spherocytes and target cells are seen in hereditary spherocytosis and thalassemia respectively. Given the man's ethnicity, G6PD deficiency is more likely than sickle cell disease. Heinz bodies are characteristic of G6PD deficiency.
  • G6PD deficiency is associated with transient episodes of intravascular hemolysis caused by exposure to an environmental factor (usually infectious agents or drugs) that produces oxidant stress. Incriminated drugs include antimalarials (e.g., primaquine), sulfonamides, nitrofurantoin, phenacetin, aspirin (in large doses), and vitamin K derivatives.

questions.text: A 42 year old man presents with a regular narrow complex tachycardia of 160 bpm suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. Which of the following is a contraindication to the use of the first line medication in this condition?
questions.solution:
Adenosine is the first line agent used in PSVT.

Adenosine can produce profound bronchospasm especially in asthmatics, and it is contraindicated.

Contraindications to adenosine:

  • Hypersensitivity to adenosine or any component of the formulation
  • Second- or third-degree AV block
  • Sick sinus syndrome, or symptomatic bradycardia (except in patients with a functioning artificial pacemaker)known or suspected bronchoconstrictive or bronchospastic lung disease
  • AVRT or pre excited AF in WPW syndrome

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with acute exacerbation of COPD presented with worsening palpitations. The ECG tracing is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT) is a rapid, irregular atrial rhythm arising from multiple ectopic foci within the atria.
  • Usually seen in patients with advanced respiratory failure with increased risk in those treated with beta agonists and theophyllines.

Multifocal atrial tachycardia - criteria

  • Heart rate > 100 bpm (usually 100-150 bpm; may be as high as 250 bpm).
  • Irregularly irregular rhythm with varying PP, PR and RR intervals.
  • At least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead.
  • Isoelectric baseline between P-waves (i.e. no flutter waves).

questions.text: Among the four deep cerebellar nuclei, which one is involved in balance and connected to vestibulo-cerebellum?
questions.solution:
• There are three functional divisions of cerebellum.
    • Cortico Cerebellar - Motor planning
    • Vestibulocerebellum - Balance and equilibrium
    • Spinocerebellum - Motor execution
  • Deep cerebellar nuclei linked to functional divisions are

Key Takeaway: Nucleus fastigial is involved in balance and connected to vestibulo-cerebellum.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman is referred to you for investigation of headache. She has had headaches for 10 years, which is associated with photophobia and nausea and is not associated with any red flag signs. Initially it responded to proprietary painkillers, but she is currently using the maximum dose of paracetamol, tramadol and diclofenac. The headaches are frequent throughout the day and last for hours. There are no associated visual symptoms. Which is the next best management step?
questions.solution:
This question deals with a patient having a primary headache disorder, which stopped responding to analgesics over a period of continuous use of analgesics. This condition is called the Medication Overuse Headache (MOH). MOH is common in patients with migraine and it impairs the effectiveness of preventive therapy used in migraine.

The treatment of MOH is gradual withdrawal of medications. The residual head ache that persists after the stoppage of analgesics indicates the primary headache disorder.

Once the dose of analgesics are brought down substantially, the preventive medicine should be added.

For patients with significant comorbidities or those with failed OP withdrawal of analgesics, IP care is required. Once in IP, the analgesics can be withdrawn completely, with IV fluids and anti emetics. Clonidine can be given for opioid withdrawal. IV analgesics can be used.

questions.text:
A 54 year old man has been progressively getting more confused. His symptoms begin about three years ago when he noticed leg stiffness. At present his entire body feels stiff and he has a resting tremor in the limbs. His writing has become small. Over the last six months, he has developed hallucinations and reports seeing ghost figures, and is also becoming forgetful, on one occasion leaving the gas cooker fire on.
On examination, his mini-mental score was 10/30. He has increased tone throughout which is spastic and cogwheeling. There is a tremor in all limbs. Cranial nerve examination reveals mild restriction of conjugate upgaze eye movement. His gait was shuffling with a tendency to fall backwards.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Whenever we come across a question on dementia, we have to see what are the cognitive domains that are affected, that will help us reach a diagnosis. Dementia is the term used to denote loss of cognitive functions like memory, language, execution, visuospatial skills, attention, learning and social skills. In addition to the cognitive decline, they may have additional neurological findings according to the disease.

Here, the patient has forgetfulness, along with extrapyramidal symptoms, visual hallucinations. This is basically a dementia syndrome. The various diseases causing dementia can be identified by the symptoms that accompany them.

The given combination of parkinsonian features and memory loss is characteristic of Lewy Body Dementia.

DLB is characterized by:

  • A relative sparing of episodic memory compared to other dementias
  • With sever executive dysfunction, in attention and visuospatial problems.
  • Fluctuations in the symptoms.
  • There will be REM sleep disorder characterized by enacting during dreams and injuring others.
  • Early visual hallucinations is prominent.
  • Capgras syndrome is seen, where care taker is mistaken for an imposter.

Parkinsons disease can also present with dementia symptoms, but there will be history of long standing motor symptoms. If Parkinsonian Features occur along with or after the development of neuropsychiatric symptoms, DLB should be suspected.

Pick's Disease is the other name for Frontotemporal dementia. It is characterized by executive dysfunction, social disinhibition and language dysfunction. The neurological findings that may be seen include dystonia, vertical gaze palsy.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for difficulty moving and memory problems.
On examination he has mask-like facies and a pill-rolling tremor. His gait is bradykinetic. He is unable to look down and has been falling frequently only in the last few months. He is not orthostatic on examination
Which of the histopathological changes in this disease are similar to those found in the listed conditions?
questions.solution:
History given in the question is suggestive of Parkinson's disease.

Parkinson's disease pathology: synucleiopathy

Multiple system atrophy is an alpha-synucleinopathy.

Prion disease has spongiform changes.

CPEO is a mitochondrial disorder.

Tabes dorsalis is a result of inflammation from a syphilis infection.
